Subsection Title: None of the SEC, any state securities commission or any other regulatory authority has approved or disapproved of the notes or determined if this offering memorandum is truthful or complete. Any representation to the contrary is a criminal offense.
Subsubsection Text: We expect that delivery of the notes will be made against payment therefor on or about          , 2023, which will be the        business day following the date of pricing of the notes, or “T+      .” Under Rule 15c6 ii ----- 1 under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the “Exchange Act”), trades in the secondary market generally are required to settle in two business days, unless the parties to any such trade expressly agree otherwise. Accordingly, purchasers who wish to trade notes before the second business day prior to the anticipated settlement date will be required, by virtue of the fact that the notes initially will settle in T+  , to specify an alternate settlement cycle at the time of any such trade to prevent a failed settlement. Such purchasers should consult their own advisors. The initial purchasers may engage in transactions that stabilize, maintain or otherwise affect the price of the notes, including over-allotment, stabilizing and short-covering transactions in the notes and the imposition of a penalty bid during and after this offering of the notes. Such stabilization, if commenced, may be discontinued at any time. For a description of these activities, see “Plan of Distribution.” We have prepared this offering memorandum solely for use in connection with the offer of the notes to persons reasonably believed to be qualified institutional buyers in reliance on Rule 144A and to certain non-U.S. persons in offshore transactions outside the United States in reliance on Regulation S. You agree that you will hold the information contained in this offering memorandum and the transactions contemplated hereby in confidence. You may not distribute this offering memorandum or disclose any information in this offering memorandum to any person, other than a person retained to advise you in connection with the purchase of the notes. By accepting delivery of this offering memorandum, you agree to the foregoing and to make no copies of this offering memorandum or any documents referred to herein. We and the initial purchasers may reject any offer to purchase the notes in whole or in part, sell less than the entire principal amount of the notes offered hereby or allocate to any purchaser less than all of the notes for which it has subscribed. THE NOTES ARE SUBJECT TO RESTRICTIONS ON TRANSFERABILITY AND RESALE AND MAY NOT BE TRANSFERRED OR RESOLD EXCEPT AS PERMITTED UNDER THE SECURITIES ACT AND APPLICABLE STATE SECURITIES LAWS PURSUANT TO REGISTRATION OR EXEMPTION THEREFROM. PROSPECTIVE PURCHASERS SHOULD BE AWARE THAT THEY MAY BE REQUIRED TO BEAR THE FINANCIAL RISKS OF THIS INVESTMENT FOR AN INDEFINITE PERIOD OF TIME. SEE “PLAN OF DISTRIBUTION” AND “TRANSFER RESTRICTIONS.” Each person receiving this offering memorandum acknowledges that (1) it has been afforded an opportunity to request and to review, and it has received, all additional information considered by it to be necessary to verify the accuracy of or to supplement the information contained in this offering memorandum, (2) it has not relied upon the initial purchasers or any person affiliated with the initial purchasers in connection with its investigation of the accuracy of such information or its investment decision, (3) this offering memorandum relates to an offering that is exempt from registration under the Securities Act and may not comply in important respects with SEC rules that would apply to an offering document relating to a public offering of securities and (4) no person has been authorized to give information or to make any representation concerning us, this offering or the notes, other than as contained in this offering memorandum, in connection with an investor’s examination of us and the terms of this offering. Upon completion of the Transactions (as defined below under “Summary—The Transactions”), Univar will not be subject to the periodic reporting and other informational requirements of the Exchange Act. Under the terms of the indenture, we will agree that for so long as any of the notes remain outstanding, we will provide limited information to the Trustee and holders of the notes pursuant to the requirements of the indenture. See “Description of Notes—Certain Covenants—Reports and Other Information.” In addition, we will also agree to make available to any holder or beneficial owner of the notes or any prospective purchaser of the notes designated by a holder or beneficial owner of the notes, in connection with any sale of the notes, the information required to be delivered pursuant to Rule 144A(d)(4) under the Securities Act. This offering memorandum contains summaries of certain agreements that we have entered into or will enter into in connection with the Transactions, such as the indenture, the escrow agreement (if applicable), the intercreditor agreements and collateral documents, the credit agreement governing the Term Loan Facility and the credit agreement governing the ABL Facility. The descriptions contained in this offering memorandum of these agreements do not purport to be complete and are subject to, and qualified in their entirety by reference to, the iii ----- definitive agreements. Copies of the definitive agreements will be made available without charge to you in response to a written or oral request to us.

Section Title: NO REVIEW BY THE SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION
Subsubsection Text: The information included in this offering memorandum does not conform to information that would be required if this offering was made pursuant to a registration statement filed with the SEC. This offering memorandum, as well as any other documents in connection with this offering, will not be reviewed by the SEC. There are no registration rights associated with the notes, and we have no intention to offer notes registered under the Securities Act in exchange for the notes offered in this offering or to file a registration statement with respect to the notes. The indenture will not be qualified under the Trust Indenture Act of 1939, as amended.

This offering memorandum contains historical financial statements and financial information of Univar for the fiscal years ended December 31, 2020, 2021 and 2022 and for the three months ended March 31, 2022 and 2023. Univar’s fiscal year ends on December 31 of each year. The Issuer was formed on March 9, 2023 and has conducted limited activities prior to the Transactions. Therefore, no historical financial statements or financial information of the Issuer are presented in this offering memorandum. This offering memorandum also presents unaudited pro forma financial information. The unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated balance sheet data as of March 31, 2023 gives effect to the Transactions as if they occurred on March 31, 2023. The unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated statement of operations data gives effect to the Transactions as if they occurred on January 1, 2022. The unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated statement of operations data for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, including the historical financial data and pro forma adjustments for the Transactions, has been calculated by subtracting the unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated statement of operations data for the three months ended March 31, 2022 from the unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated statement of operations data for the year ended December 31, 2022, and then adding the unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated statement of operations data for the three months ended March 31, 2023. The unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated balance sheet as of March 31, 2023 and the unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated statements of operations for the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, the three months ended March 31, 2023, the three months ended March 31, 2022 and the fiscal year ended December 31, 2022 are based on the historical consolidated audited annual and unaudited interim financial statements of Univar. The unaudited pro forma data has been derived from and should be read in conjunction with the historical consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. The unaudited pro forma information presented in this offering memorandum is for informational purposes only and is not necessarily indicative of what our financial position or results of operations would have been had the Transactions been completed as of the dates indicated. In addition, the unaudited pro forma information presented in this offering memorandum does not purport to project our future financial position or operating results. The information included in this offering memorandum is not intended to, and does not, comply with all of the disclosure requirements of the SEC that would apply if this offering were being made pursuant to a registration statement filed with the SEC. Additionally, the financial information included in this offering memorandum will not be subject to review by the SEC. Compliance with such requirements could require the modification or exclusion of certain financial measures and/or other information included in this offering memorandum and the inclusion of certain information not included in this offering memorandum. Unless otherwise indicated or the context otherwise requires, references in this offering memorandum to “we,” “us,” “our” and the “Company” refer to the Issuer and each of its consolidated subsidiaries after giving effect to the Merger. iv -----

We present EBITDA, Reported Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Before Normalization in this offering memorandum because we believe they provide investors with additional information to measure our performance and evaluate our ability to service our indebtedness. We believe that the presentation of EBITDA, Reported Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Before Normalization is appropriate to provide additional information to investors about certain material non-cash items and about certain items that we do not expect to continue at the same level in the future as well as other items. Further, we believe Reported Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Before Normalization provide a meaningful measure of operating profitability because we use the metrics for evaluating our business performance and understanding certain significant items. EBITDA, Reported Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Before Normalization are not presentations made in accordance with Generally Accepted Accounting Principles in the United States (“GAAP”), and our use of the terms EBITDA, Reported Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Before Normalization varies from others in our industry. EBITDA, Reported Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Before Normalization should not be considered as alternatives to net income or any other performance measures derived in accordance with GAAP as measures of operating performance or cash flows as measures of liquidity. EBITDA, Reported Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Before Normalization have important limitations as analytical tools, and you should not consider them in isolation or as substitutes for analysis of our results as reported under GAAP. For example, EBITDA: - excludes certain tax payments that may represent a reduction in cash available to us; - does not reflect any cash capital expenditure requirements for the assets being depreciated and amortized that may have to be replaced in the future; - does not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs; - does not reflect the significant interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary to service interest or principal payments, on our indebtedness; and - excludes the impact of certain non-operating accounts, such as interest income. In addition, Reported Adjusted EBITDA: - excludes impairment charges; - excludes the impact of gain and losses on the sale of businesses; - excludes transaction and integration related expenses; - excludes stock-based compensation expense; - excludes restructuring charges, employee severance costs and facility closure costs; - excludes multi-employer pension plan exit liability, certain pension gains and non-operating retirement benefits; v ----- - excludes gain on sale of property, plant and equipment; - excludes the impact of gains and losses due to foreign currencies; - excludes the impact of undesignated derivate instruments, debt refinancing costs and fair value adjustments for warrants; - excludes discrete tax items; and - excludes certain other adjustments, which may include non-recurring and/or non-cash income and expenses. In addition, Adjusted EBITDA: - includes the impact of transactional gains and losses due to foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations; - aligns rent expense, which is recorded on a straight-line basis, to actual cash outflows per the lease agreements, in accordance with GAAP; - excludes the impact of other non-recurring items, such as sublease income and an environmental provision, as well as the equal and offsetting insurance recovery receivable; and - excludes certain net losses from unconsolidated joint ventures net of cash dividends received. Further, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA: - excludes the impact of the supply chain disruption and destocking in 2022, including a normalization adjustment for temporary pricing surges within the first three fiscal quarters of 2022, as well as subsequent destocking in the fourth quarter of 2022; - includes estimated cost savings and acquisition related synergies; - excludes the impact of exited businesses and includes the pre-acquisition impact of acquired businesses; and - does not reflect the impact of earnings, charges or expenses resulting from matters that we may consider not to be indicative of our ongoing operations. Further, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Before Normalization: - includes the impact of the supply chain disruption and destocking in 2022 that is excluded from the calculation of Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA. Reported Adjusted EBITDA for historical periods is consistent with the basis of presentation of “Adjusted EBITDA” in Univar’s prior public filings and the notes to the condensed consolidated financial statements included in this offering memorandum. Adjusted EBITDA as presented in this offering memorandum differs from the presentation of “Adjusted EBITDA” in Univar’s prior public filings for the reasons stated above. Our definitions of Reported Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Before Normalization allow us to add back certain non-cash and non-recurring charges or costs that are deducted in calculating net income. However, some of these are expenses that involved cash, may recur, vary greatly and are difficult to predict. They can represent the effect of long-term strategies as opposed to short-term results. In addition, certain of these expenses can represent the reduction of cash that could be used for other corporate purposes. vi ----- Because of these limitations, we rely primarily on our GAAP results and use EBITDA, Reported Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Before Normalization only supplementally. For more information on the use of non-GAAP financial information, see “Summary—Summary Historical and Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Data” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Non-GAAP Financial Measures.”

We include statements and information in this offering memorandum concerning our industry ranking and the markets in which we operate, including our general expectations and market opportunity, which are based on information from independent industry organizations and other third-party sources. We have not independently verified any third-party information and such information is inherently imprecise. In addition, projections, assumptions and estimates of the future performance of the industry in which we operate and our future performance are necessarily subject to a high degree of uncertainty and risk due to a variety of factors, including those described in “Risk Factors” in this offering memorandum. These and other factors could cause results to differ materially from those expressed in the estimates made by the independent parties and by us.

This offering memorandum contains references to our trademarks and service marks, including “Univar”, “Univar Solutions”, and the stylized Univar Solutions logo. Solely for convenience, trademarks and trade names referred to in this offering memorandum may appear without the [®] or TM symbols, but such references are not intended to indicate, in any way, that we will not assert, to the fullest extent under applicable law, our rights or the rights of the applicable licensor to these trademarks and trade names. Other trademarks and tradenames appearing in this offering memorandum are the property of their respective holders. We do not intend our use or display of other companies’ trade names, trademarks or service marks to imply a relationship with, or endorsement or sponsorship of us by, any other companies.

Certain statements in this offering memorandum, other than historical information, may be considered “forward-looking statements” and are subject to various risks, uncertainties and assumptions. Statements that are not historical in nature, and which may be identified by the use of words such as “may,” “should,” “could,” “believe,” “predict,” “potential,” “continue,” “plan,” “intend,” “expect,” “anticipate,” “future,” “project,” “estimate,” and similar expressions (or the negative of such expressions) are forward-looking statements. Any forward-looking statements contained in this offering memorandum are qualified by these cautionary statements. Forward-looking statements are made based on our current expectations and beliefs concerning future events and, therefore, involve a number of assumptions, risks and uncertainties, including those described under “Risk Factors.” Should one or more of these risks or uncertainties materialize, or should underlying assumptions prove incorrect, actual results may differ materially from those anticipated, estimated or expected. There are a number of important factors that could cause actual results or events to differ materially from those indicated by such forward-looking statements, including, among other things, risks relating to the expected timing, consummation, and financial benefits of the Merger. Other risk factors include, but are not limited to: - general economic conditions, particularly fluctuations in industrial production and consumption and the timing and extent of economic downturns, and increased competitive pressures, including as a result of competitor consolidation; - significant changes in the business strategies of producers or in the operations of our customers; - delivery failures or hazards and risks related to our operations and the hazardous materials we handle, potential inability to obtain adequate insurance coverage; vii ----- - potential supply chain disruptions; - significant changes in the pricing, demand and availability of chemicals; - increased competitive pressures, including as a result of competitor consolidation; - potential cybersecurity incidents, including security breaches; - the broad spectrum of laws and regulations that we are subject to, including extensive environmental, health and safety laws and regulations and changes in tax laws; - an inability to generate sufficient working capital; - transportation related challenges, including increases in transportation and fuel costs, changes in our relationship with third party transportation providers, and ability to attract and retain qualified drivers; - accidents, safety failures, environmental damage, product quality issues; - ongoing and potential litigation, product liability claims and recalls, and other environmental, legal and regulatory risks; - challenges associated with international operations; - an inability to integrate the business and systems of companies we acquire, including failure to realize the anticipated benefits of such acquisitions; - possible impairment of goodwill and intangible assets; - our ability to attract or retain a qualified and diverse workforce; - negative developments affecting our pension plans and multi-employer pensions; - labor disruptions associated with the unionized portion of our workforce; - our ability to execute on our initiatives and goals related to environmental, social, and governance (“ESG”) matters and the increasing legal and regulatory focus on ESG; - our indebtedness, the restrictions imposed by, and costs associated with, our debt instruments, and our ability to obtain additional financing; - uncertainties as to the timing of the Merger; - the risk that the Merger may not be completed in a timely manner or at all; - the possibility that any or all of the various conditions to the consummation of the Merger may not be satisfied or waived; - the occurrence of any event, change or other circumstance that could give rise to the termination of the Merger Agreement (as defined below under “Summary—The Transactions”); - the effect of the announcement or pendency of the transactions contemplated by the Merger Agreement on our ability to retain and hire key personnel, our ability to maintain relationships with our customers, suppliers and others with whom we do business, or our operating results and business generally; viii ----- - risks related to diverting management’s attention from our ongoing business operations; - the amount of costs, fees and expenses related to the Merger; - the risk that stockholder litigation in connection with the transactions contemplated by the Merger Agreement may result in significant costs of defense, indemnification and liability; - our ability to realize (including within the time frames contemplated) any or all of the estimated cost savings and synergies, including those included in the calculation of Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA; and - the other risks described under “Risk Factors.” We caution you that the foregoing list of important factors may not contain all of the material factors that are important to you. In addition, in light of these risks and uncertainties, the matters referred to in the forwardlooking statements contained in this offering memorandum may not in fact occur. Estimated costs and cost savings are based on the current estimates of the Issuer, but they involve risks, uncertainties, assumptions and other factors that may cause actual results, performance or achievements of the Issuer to be materially different from any future results, performance or achievements expressed or implied by estimates. The forward-looking statements made in this offering memorandum relate only to events as of the date on which the statements were made. Except as may be required by law, we undertake no obligation to update our forward-looking statements to reflect events and circumstances after the date on which the statements were made or to reflect the occurrence of unanticipated events. ix -----

We source and inventory commodity and specialty chemicals and ingredients in large quantities such as barge loads, railcars or full truck loads directly from producers and break down the bulk quantities to repackage, market, sell and distribute smaller quantities to our customers. In addition to selling and distributing commodity and specialty chemicals and ingredients, we use our transportation and warehousing infrastructure, along with our broad knowledge of chemicals and hazardous materials handling to provide important distribution and specialized services for our producers and our customers. We also have state-of-the-art solution centers at locations across the globe, consisting of formulation labs, development and research centers, and test kitchens, with specialized industry expertise and innovative technical capabilities to help our customers address their technical challenges and accelerate product development cycles. Each of these locations is staffed by a team of chemists and food scientists, many with doctorate-level educations. At the heart of our business model are our highly trained professionals with deep industry experience within the specific markets they serve. We serve a diverse set of end markets and regions, with no end market accounting for more than 18% of our net sales for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2022. The following charts illustrate the geographical and end market diversity of our net sales for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2022: 2 ----- 3 ----- We believe that the following characteristics of our model, among others, help differentiate us in the market and allow us to compete across our end markets: - we operate an expansive North American site network and approximately 80% of our U.S. manufacturing GDP is located within a 60-minute drive time from one or more of our facilities; - we offer a highly diversified product portfolio and maintain appropriate inventory levels throughout the year to ensure security of supply to our customers; - we have invested in a strong digital platform that allows us to identify orders, target customers, access real-time pricing information and ensure the availability of freight-logical product where and when it is needed; - we offer competitive pricing for our products while delivering attractive levels of profitability; and - we are contracted and work closely with the leading suppliers in the industry and maintain an expert sales force with deep ties to customers to market and sell their product into the market. We have established clear goals within our C&S channel. We are targeting organic growth of over 100 basis points above GDP and stable gross profit margins of approximately 22% over the next three to five years. We also have clear strategic priorities for C&S to ensure we continue to gain share within our core markets and continue our track record of delivering strong growth, including: - execution of strategic capital investments to ensure high levels of service, improved safety and the ability to maximize growth in a dynamic market; - continuing to compete successfully at the local level with global scale, matching the intensity of our more regional competitors with our advantageous size and scale; and - remaining “Easy to Do Business With” for our customers and suppliers as a trusted distributor in our industry. _I&S. Our Ingredients and Specialties channel serves a more value added, higher-growth portion of the_ market tailored to specific end market requirements. For each I&S market, we have dedicated sales, marketing, product management and technical professionals with deep industry knowledge of the markets they serve. We represent approximately 500 strategic specialty and ingredient chemical suppliers and sell their portfolios to approximately 42,000 customer locations around the world. These specialty products are typically sold in lower volumes, but at a higher gross profit (exclusive of depreciation), than commodity products. These products also tend to provide “sticky” business as they become vital components to customers’ procurement needs. In I&S, sustained growth can be achieved by leveraging salesforce effectiveness, delivering solutions through industry expertise, technical capabilities, formulation support and our comprehensive supply chain infrastructure. I&S focuses on seven global markets and is serviced through our Life Sciences (Beauty & Personal Care, Food Ingredients and Pharmaceutical Ingredients) and Industrial Solutions (CASE, Homecare & Industrial Cleaning and Lubricant & Metalworking Fluids) businesses. We believe that the following characteristics of our model, among others, help differentiate us in the market and allow us to compete across our customer and end markets: - strong formulation know-how and application laboratories to innovate with customers, including through our industry-leading laboratory capabilities; - ability to meet our customers’ needs with a comprehensive product portfolio and industry focus sales, marketing and product management; - reliable “on time in full” delivery and supply assurance, underpinned by strong relationships between customers and company service representatives; and - partnerships with high-quality suppliers and brands with high-quality products across end markets, including securing exclusive relationships for premium parts of our portfolio where we operate symbiotically with our suppliers. 4 ----- 5 -----

We are a leading global distributor of commodity and specialty chemicals and ingredients, as well as a provider of value-added services, to customers across a wide range of diverse industries. We purchase chemicals and ingredients from thousands of producers worldwide to warehouse, repackage, blend, dilute, transport, and sell those materials safely to nearly 100,000 customer locations across approximately 120 countries. Our go-to-market approach focuses on leveraging the scale of our operations and our local industry and geographic knowledge to create differentiated value for our customers and suppliers. This is primarily achieved through our Chemicals & Services (“C&S”) channel, through which we can leverage the scale of our operations and is intensely focused on customer service, and our Ingredients & Specialties (“I&S”) channel, which focuses on specialty chemicals and ingredients paired with in-depth technical expertise. This dualchannel approach allows us to meet the specific needs of each customer across their entire product development, commercialization, and raw material purchasing journey, creating value across the entire customer production chain. Our C&S channel features a broad portfolio of commodity products and we believe that our focus on customer service in this business channel allows us to gain a competitive advantage over other players operating in the market. Our I&S channel leverages the breadth of our supplier and customer relationships and a technically focused sales process aimed at achieving new authorizations and customer and volume retention. We operate an extensive worldwide chemical and ingredient distribution network, including approximately 9,700 employees and 600 facilities, supported by the largest private transportation fleet in the industry: approximately 4,900 tractors, tankers and trailers; and approximately 2,500 railcars, 120 rail and barge terminals and 20 deep sea terminals, focused on timely and safe delivery to a spectrum of customers, large and small. With our global sales force, a vast supplier network, unparalleled logistics know-how, deep market and regulatory knowledge, world-class formulation and recipe development, and industry-leading digital tools, we are committed to helping customers and suppliers anticipate and navigate today’s challenges and capture the meaningful growth opportunities that exist in their industries. Beyond traditional distribution services, our value-added services include e-commerce, digital marketing, chemical waste management, on-site storage, packaging, private label and technical application and formulation support for industries such as Beauty and Personal Care, Food, Pharma, Coatings, Adhesives, Sealants and Elastomers (“CASE”), Lubricants and Metalworking, Homecare and Industrial Cleaning, 1 ----- Agricultural, Water Treatment, and Electronics. Our scale, along with our dense logistics network, longstanding regulatory permits, exclusive product offering of premier brands, centralized business technology infrastructure, industry-leading safety record, and value-added services, along with established relationships with the leading chemicals and ingredients producers in our industry allow us to meet the end market, technical development, and material supply needs of our customers, while serving as an extension of our premier suppliers. This approach allows us to execute an intense focus on service, while lowering costs. While the global chemical distribution industry is large and highly fragmented, with thousands of distributors, it represents a relatively small portion of all chemical industry sales. While the total chemical and ingredient industry is projected to grow at rates close to the gross national product of the countries in which we operate around the world, the distributed chemicals portion of the industry is projected to grow at a faster rate as producers and customers increasingly realize the economic benefits of this channel. Suppliers rely on us to warehouse, repackage, transport, market and sell their products as a way to expand their industry access, enhance their geographic reach, lower their cost to serve, and grow their business. Customers who purchase products and services from us benefit from a lower total cost of ownership, as they are able to simplify their chemical and ingredient sourcing process through access to just-in-time delivery, excellent product availability and selection, packaging, mixing, blending and technical expertise. They also rely on us for safe and secure delivery and off-loading of chemicals fully compliant with increasing local and federal regulations. Chemical distributors play an essential role within the global chemical and ingredient value chain by providing customers of all sizes access to mission-critical chemicals that create value-added products. While certain chemical and ingredient producers choose to directly serve large, global end users, there are also thousands of smaller, regional customers who may be more economically served by distributors given their more “local” reach and last-mile expertise. For the three months ended March 31, 2023, we generated $2.7 billion in net sales, $83.1 million of net income and $215.4 million in Reported Adjusted EBITDA. For the fiscal year ended December 31, 2022, we generated $11.5 billion in net sales, $545.3 million of net income and $1,045.9 million in Reported Adjusted EBITDA. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, we generated $11.3 billion in net sales, $447.6 million of net income, $972.7 million in Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and $1,028.0 million in Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Before Normalization. For a reconciliation of non-GAAP metrics, see “—Summary Historical and Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Data.”

We believe that we are well positioned to drive profitable growth, increase our market share and capitalize on industry outsourcing trends by focusing on our key initiatives to Streamline, Innovate, and Grow. _Streamline. We are committed to continuously improving our operating performance and lowering_ our costs per transaction. In particular, we seek to: - align our business teams with identified growth opportunities in customer end markets, product markets, services, and industries in a way that narrows focus and increases accountability; - increase our use of digital tools to simplify tasks, lower costs and improve customer experience; - continue to use Lean Six Sigma methodologies to deliver project-by-project productivity gains; - increase the cost efficiency of our warehouses, terminals, tank farms and logistics, and improve our net working capital efficiency; - deliver a compelling customer value proposition by providing simplified sourcing, cost effective just-in-time delivery and managed inventory along with value-added services; and - continue to build on our industry leading safety performance, and sustainability initiatives as a differentiator with both customers and producers. We have identified significant incremental opportunities to improve efficiencies and reduce costs throughout the organization. The five key areas to be targeted span across: (1) Organization, general and administration; (2) Fleet & logistics Improvement; (3) Procurement; (4) Go-to-Market strategy; and (5) Warehouse improvement & commercial efficiencies. Between approximately $114 and $211 million of cost saving opportunities have been identified by an independent third-party study, approximately $40 million of which was already announced to the market in 2022 by Univar as a part of the Value Capture program. We are estimating that we will be able to achieve an additional $75 million of cost savings above previous 2023 targets and believe this will take between 12 and 18 months to realize with one-time implementation costs of approximately $37 million. _Innovate. We intend to deliver our digital transformation by combining the most advanced ERP and_ smart asset “Internet of Things” technology. We intend to enrich the customer and supplier experience with market leading tools and quality processes that will further separate us from our competitors. We expect that our superior market intelligence and analytics capabilities will allow us to predict trends and lead innovations. We believe our digital expertise will help us deliver end-to-end supply chain solutions, from our suppliers’ manufacturing facilities right through to our customers’ machines, allowing us to work as an extension of their teams and networks to create a whole new level of new ecosystem for our industry. 6 ----- We believe we are well positioned to drive profitable growth and increased operational efficiency by orchestrating a multi- year digital transformation by: - continuing to introduce new, innovative digital solutions that enhance our customer experience and drive stronger customer preference and customer loyalty, thereby increasing the lifetime value of customers; - expanding our offering of digital solutions and bolstering our leadership position in the industry; - leveraging new digital solutions to enhance the experience of our supplier partners, improving their market reach and penetration and providing valuable market insights through data analytics; - digitizing our distribution network, thereby creating a more agile, transparent supply chain, resulting in improved capabilities and efficiency; and - empowering our employees with valuable, timely insights resulting in better decisions, and automating administrative functions in order to enhance employee productivity. We have built a global network of world-class solutions centers. These state-of-the-art labs and test kitchens perform a variety of services including performance testing, failure analysis, quality assurance, recipe development, and formulation development. Our chemists, food scientists, chefs and experienced formulation experts help customers innovate their products from concept to commercialization across a wide range of industries and applications. Our technical team comprises both lab-based and field-based experts, many with doctorate and other advanced degrees in their scientific field. _Grow. We believe our initiatives will allow us to outperform competitors, leading to market share_ gains. We will continue to streamline and enhance our customer experience in order to be the most customerfriendly distributor to do business with and to increase customer preference for Univar Solutions. In addition, we believe our industry-focused go-to-market strategy combined with innovative sales and marketing support and strong customer preference will lead to winning additional product authorizations from suppliers. In particular, we seek to: - further develop a highly skilled and well-equipped sales force utilizing a value-based consultative sales approach that is aligned to customer and end market needs by geography, product, service and industry specialization; - continue to increase our technical and industry-specific product and market expertise; - develop a world-class marketing capability to dynamically identify and align resources with high-growth, high value opportunities; - cultivate and maintain long-term producer relationships through deep market and product knowledge, value-based selling, reduced complexity in distribution channels and offering complementary products and services as a total solution for our customers; - offer industry leading digital solutions that drive customer and supplier preference, enhance supply chain efficiency, empower employees with valuable insights and provide new sources of profitable growth through innovation; and - evaluate strategic acquisitions to increase our presence and develop competitive advantage in attractive end markets and with products and service capabilities that benefit from our scale advantages. We are committed to developing a healthy, high-performance culture through the selection, recognition and development of our employees. We aspire to build an environment where the best people want to work and add value for our customers, producers and shareholders. We will strengthen the overall governance and efficiency of our global business operations with integrated, disciplined operating processes and by leveraging best practices.

Chemical distributors play an essential role within the global chemical value chain by providing customers of all sizes access to mission-critical chemicals that create value-added products. While certain chemical and ingredient producers choose to directly serve large, global end users, there are also thousands of 7 ----- smaller, regional customers who may be may be more economically served by distributors given their more “local” reach and last-mile expertise. Distributors fill this gap by purchasing chemicals and ingredients from producers worldwide to warehouse, repackage, blend, dilute, transport, and sell those chemicals to customers through a more regional supply chain and at volumes that may be meaningfully below traditional order sizes for producers. The chemical distribution market is highly fragmented due to the diverse range of products, services, customers, and its regionalized nature. While the industry consists of tens of thousands of players, scaled distributors have some competitive advantages due to their existing capital investment, significant logistics networks and experience operating in a highly regulated environment. As of 2022, the estimated size of the market for chemical consumption is approximately $4,800 billion, of which approximately $1,500 billion is for chemicals considered nondistributable (e.g., products that travel to customers through pipelines), resulting in a market for distributable chemical consumption of approximately $3,300 billion. Within this market, it is estimated that only 11% is currently served through distributors globally. Since 2015, the distribution market has grown steadily at approximately 3-5% year over year. From 2019-2022, the market experienced an increased growth rate of approximately 4-5%, underpinned by increased pricing throughout COVID-19 driven by supply chain constraints, which is expected to normalize in 2023. In the period from 2023 through 2027, the chemical distribution market is expected to grow at approximately 45%.

Subsubsection Title: Attractive industry with significant demand tailwinds in strong end markets to fuel long-term organic growth
Subsubsection Text: Chemicals distributors serve as key intermediaries between customers and producers to sell products that are cost-ineffective for larger producers. We are well positioned to benefit from the growing trend of chemical and ingredient producers and customers outsourcing key tasks to distributors. Third-party chemical and ingredient distribution represents a small portion of the market, with distributors underpenetrated relative to other industries (including building materials, steel, auto parts and others). However, the market remains large with global third-party chemical distribution industry sales of approximately $320 billion in 2022. Historically, chemical distribution was viewed as a channel to reach smaller customers but is increasingly important to larger customers. The relatively low current penetration rate, combined with rising regulatory requirements, an increased focus on ESG, customer regionalization, and supplier globalization, are expected to be strong tailwinds for increased outsourcing penetration across both specialty and commodity chemicals. It is a highly fragmented industry with a significant number of small, local participants; our scale provides a meaningful competitive advantage. As a full-line distributor with a strong, highly scaled supply-chain-network across a broad geographic region, we are well suited to help customers and producers consolidate their distributor relationships and lower their total costs of ownership while improving upon their service levels. Amidst a backdrop of industry-wide underinvestment in software and digitization, we have a “First Mover” advantage derived from our leading proprietary platform. Our advanced centralized business platform simplifies logistics and reduces complexity and costs. As one of the leaders in chemical and ingredient distribution, we believe we can accelerate this trend by increasing the attractiveness of our total value proposition to both customers and our suppliers.

Subsubsection Title: Truly global platform with expansive scale and market access – #1 in North America and #2 in EMEA – powered by centralized business technology solution
Subsubsection Text: We operate one of the most extensive chemical and ingredient distribution networks in the world, comprising more than 600 distribution facilities, approximately 90 million gallons of chemical storage tank capacity and hundreds of tractors, railcars, tankers and trailers operating daily through our facilities. Our rail and barge network, which consists of approximately 4,900 tractors, tankers and trailers, approximately 2,500 railcars, 120 rail & barge terminals, and 20 deep sea terminals, provides an irreplicable logistics network. This highly responsive service level enables our customers to lower their inventory levels while relying on the security of supply our scale and supplier relationship enables us to provide. 9 ----- The images below display show the locations of our distribution centers, site locations and industryleading density compared to our competitors, respectively: Our scaled business model and numerous access points to the market enables a high level of diversification across suppliers, customers, products and end markets: - our top 10 customers represent approximately 6% of our sales; - we offer over 15,000 products within our portfolio, with our top 15 products representing less than 20% of our gross profit; and - none of our end markets represents more than approximately 18% of our sales. We believe our purchasing power and global procurement relationships provide us with advantages over local and regional competitors due to economies of scale. We purchase thousands of different chemicals and ingredients from thousands of producers with flexible supply agreements without specific obligations to buy, allowing us to manage our working capital. Additionally, many of our supply relationships for premier brand are exclusive, providing us “sticky” business opportunities with additional pricing power.

Subsubsection Title: Unique value proposition, positioning the business as the top choice for customers
Subsubsection Text: Quality of service and maintaining close connections to customers is critical in distribution and an area where we differentiate ourselves against our competitors. Our model and go-to-market approach benefit our customers in multiple ways and we provide a range of value-added services beyond simple product transportation, including: - safe and responsible handling, warehousing, and delivery with industry leading safety and security ratings; - packaging sized to fit customers’ needs and tailored solutions including private label services; - a comprehensive portfolio of branded products and services that emphasize sustainable solutions; - relationships with the leading suppliers for any given product and application, including 67 new supplier authorizations in 2022; - investment in digital tools that enable customers to search, select, source, and self-serve with real-time results 24/7; - global scale, providing security of supply and reduced vendor lists; - robust sales, marketing, product management, and technical teams service the needs of the industries and regions where we do business; - technical expertise and on-demand product support; and - simplified, safe, and reliable sourcing with a lower total cost of ownership for customers. 10 -----

Subsubsection Title: Long-standing and strong relationships with premier global suppliers
Subsubsection Text: We have developed strong, long-term relationships, many spanning several decades, with the world’s premier global chemical and ingredient producers. Today, we distribute their products to more than 100,000 customer locations around the globe, from small and medium sized businesses to global corporate accounts. Our global network of over 1,300 suppliers provide diversification (our top 10 suppliers represent approximately 41% of our chemical & ingredient purchases for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2022) and supply chain resiliency while maintaining security of supply. Supplier relationship lengths of over 40 years have provided opportunities for us to integrate our service and logistics capabilities into our customers’ and producers’ business processes while promoting collaboration on supply chain optimization, marketing and other revenue enhancement strategies. We are able to offer a compelling and industry leading value proposition to each of our suppliers, which underpins our ability to retain and expand our product offering. Key points of differentiation include: - expand supplier reach by providing local market and industry specific knowledge and presence; - business intelligence allows suppliers to focus on production rather than customer service; - leading digital infrastructure to reduce complexity and costs while driving market penetration and demand growth; and - knowledge of global trends across consumer and industrial markets to allow placing of supplier products with right customers at right time. _Representative suppliers_

Subsubsection Title: Highly resilient business model with cash generative financial profile and an inherent downside hedge
Subsubsection Text: Our distributor business model is highly resilient to recessionary periods. The earnings and cash flow we generate benefits from the substantial diversity of our customers, end markets and geographic presence. Since 2007, we have been able to consistently improve our Reported Adjusted EBITDA margin across recessionary periods including the “Great Financial Crisis” (“GFC”), the oil price crash of 2015 and 2016, and the COVID-19 pandemic, where our ability to work with both customers and suppliers to provide product at a time of global supply chain disruption led to record profitability. 11 ----- 12 ----- 13 ----- Net Debt and Ratio of Net Debt to Reported Adjusted EBITDA (in millions USD) Note: Leverage ratio represents Net Debt / Reported Adjusted EBITDA. Leverage ratio as presented in this offering memorandum differs from the presentation of “Leverage ratio” in Univar’s prior public filings.

Subsubsection Title: Value creation through the Nexeo Acquisition
Subsubsection Text: Our 2019 combination with Nexeo Solutions (“Nexeo”) solidified our position as the largest chemical and ingredients distribution sales force, broadest product offering and most efficient supply chain network in North America. The Nexeo acquisition further enhanced the profitability and scale of our business, providing us with, among other things: - approximately $130 million of acquired EBITDA (pro forma for the divestiture of Nexeo’s plastics business); - a meaningful increase in the size of the North American logistics platform, strengthening our presence in its key end markets and underpinning the buildout of a global high quality I&S organization; - an alignment of business models, go-to-market strategies, superior product offerings, and digital capabilities, which leveraged the strengths of the acquired Nexeo assets; - an expansion of our product portfolio and offering, particularly in specialty chemicals and ingredients; - a truly market-leading SAP platform, providing us access to the premier digital platform in chemical distribution, with existing integrated pricing and AI tools, with a highly synchronized integration with our existing digital solutions offering; and - formation of an all-internal team to lead the integration, proving-out our capabilities as a sector consolidator. At the time of the Nexeo acquisition, we expected the combination to deliver $100 million of annual run-rate cost savings by the third year following close. As of March 31, 2023, we had realized $125 million of run-rate cost savings, following the integration of the business, as shown in the chart below: 14 ----- Overall, the Nexeo acquisition solidified Univar Solutions’ position as a leading player in North America and transformed the business through increased scale, improved end market position, and the implementation of a high end digital platform.

Our safety culture is embedded into everything we do at Univar Solutions. Safety is foundational in planning for operations, products, processes and facilities. Specific initiatives include, among others, data driven and causality-based accident prevention work, improved process and facility controls, mandatory general education and role specific safety training, joint management-worker health and safety committees, safety audits, incident investigation and improvement measures. Our efforts have resulted in significant improvements in global safety metrics during the last seven years. We track worker injuries using the U.S. Occupational Safety & Health Administration (“OSHA”) standardized methodology of Total Case Incident Rate (“TCIR”) which is the rate of recordable injuries per 200,000 hours worked. 2022 was our safest year on record with a TCIR of 0.33, compared with 0.40 in 2021 and ahead of our 2025 target of 0.38. We believe this results in a competitive advantage by: - maintaining and improving relationships with our customers and suppliers, who view safety performance as a key criterion for vendor selection; - improving employee recruitment and retention; and - reducing the likelihood of incidents and enabling our employees to focus on their contributions. Additionally, we believe our focus on safety improves our service, productivity and financial performance. We expect that there will be a continued increase in demand for products, systems and services that meet growing customer and societal sustainability standards, expectations and preferences. We recognize that our ability to continue to provide these products and services requires our business to further advance environmentally and socially responsible means of operating, reflecting the challenges and opportunities presented through increased legal requirements, climate parameters and industry developments. We are focused on demonstrating our commitment to these expectations through our global sustainability goals, which help us focus on reducing our contribution to global climate change while addressing remediation, reducing resource use, progressing responsible sourcing and bringing more sustainable solutions to market. In 2018, we became a signatory to the United Nations Global Compact, reaffirming our ongoing commitments to responsible business, and in 2019 adopted ‘Advancing a Circular 15 ----- Economy’ as a goal to 2021. In 2021, we developed and shared longer term ESG goals to 2025, 2030 and 2050. Throughout 2022 we continued to implement our strategies to drive progress on these goals. We incorporate ESG initiatives into our business values and priorities of safety, sustainability and value creation. We continually strive to improve our industry leading safety record, reduce our environmental impact and increase transparency. In 2022, we demonstrated our ongoing commitment to ESG practices and our purpose to help keep our communities healthy, fed, clean and safe with net sales of 8% related to food ingredients, 7% related to homecare and industrial cleaning, 5% related to pharmaceutical ingredients and finished products, 4% related to industrial and municipal water treatment and 2% related to chemical waste removal. In 2022, we dedicated resources to supporting our customers on their sustainability journeys, enhanced our sustainable and natural products portfolio and focused on developing sustainable formulations and services.

Our management team is led by our Chief Executive Officer, David Jukes, who has been with us for over 21 years and has over 39 years of experience in the chemical and ingredient distribution industry. Since mid-2012, our senior management team has implemented an enhanced business strategy and successfully transformed our pricing structure, sales force effectiveness, capital efficiency and acquisition and integration strategy. Our management team has experience operating under both public and private ownership and is therefore well-positioned to lead us in our next phase of growth. 16 ----- Since becoming the CEO in 2018, David and the team have transformed our business into a business with over $1 billion Reported Adjusted EBITDA in 2022 and have created an organization with higher margins, lower exposure to cyclical end markets, and have executed the transformational integration of Nexeo into Univar Solutions’ DNA. This management team will continue to lead our organization following the transaction.

We derive our strength and competitive advantage from our global scale and capabilities, comprised of transportation, storage infrastructure, exclusive authorizations of premier brands, depth and breadth of product offering, a trained, highly skilled salesforce, industry-leading safety, regulatory, and quality, sustainability leadership, long-standing relationships with producers, and technical differentiation, along with our industry-leading service levels. Our private fleet enables us to provide same day and next day service to many of our customers, which would not be feasible through many common carriers. This results in a higher degree of security and reliability to our customers, as we are able to control our supply chain and manage our costs better than if we were on the open marketplace. In addition, our propriety technology platform enables us to centralize our data and exchange information in real-time. This is highly scalable for customers, suppliers, markets, regions, and ensures our success in the digital future. Management discipline around data and analytics drives superior demand planning, pricing, optimization of our operations, and last mile expertise to control the inherent complexity of the distribution business. Our channel approach to market across C&S and I&S allows us to meet the service, portfolio and technical needs of our global customer base in a manner that is relevant to their specific industry and geographic needs, providing a small distributor feel of intimacy to our customers. Coupling this with our scale, network, and intense focus on service allows us to win differentially in the market. Overall, our ability to lead across the factors that matter most to our customers across both channels enables us to be one of the leaders across the chemical distribution industry. 8 -----

On March 13, 2023, Univar entered into an Agreement and Plan of Merger (the “Merger Agreement”) with Windsor Parent, L.P., a Delaware limited partnership (“Parent”), and Windsor Merger Sub, Inc., a Delaware corporation and an indirect wholly owned subsidiary of Parent (“Merger Sub”). Parent and Merger Sub are affiliates of funds managed by affiliates of Apollo Global Management, Inc. (“Apollo”) and Platinum Falcon B 2018 RSC Limited, an indirect wholly owned subsidiary of the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority (“ADIA”). Holdings and the Issuer are wholly owned subsidiaries of Parent and Merger Sub is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Issuer. The Merger Agreement provides that, among other things, and on the terms and subject to the conditions of 17 ----- the Merger Agreement, (i) Merger Sub will merge with and into Univar (the “Merger”), with Univar surviving the Merger as an indirect wholly owned subsidiary of Parent and (ii) at the effective time of the Merger (the “Effective Time”), each issued and outstanding share of common stock of Univar, par value $0.01 per share (a “Share”) (other than (a) certain Shares owned by (x) Univar as treasury stock or otherwise, (y) Holdings or Merger Sub or (z) any direct or indirect wholly owned subsidiary of Holdings (other than Merger Sub) or of Univar, in each case immediately prior to the Effective Time, (b) Shares issued and outstanding immediately prior to the Effective Time which are held by stockholders who have properly demanded appraisal for such Shares pursuant to Section 262 of the General Corporation Law of the State of Delaware and have complied with and have not waived, effectively withdrawn or lost their right to appraisal under Delaware law with respect to such Shares, and (c) Shares covered by share awards granted subject to any time-based vesting, forfeiture or other lapse restrictions), will be automatically converted into the right to receive $36.15 per Share in cash without interest. In accordance with the Merger Agreement, Merger Sub may acquire certain Canadian assets of Univar on the day prior to the Merger Closing Date. The issuance of the notes may occur prior to the completion of the Merger. If so, on the issue date, pending consummation of the Merger, the gross proceeds from this offering of the notes will be deposited into a segregated escrow account pledged on a first-priority basis as collateral for the benefit of holders of the notes (with J.P. Morgan Chase Bank, N.A., acting as escrow agent, pursuant to an escrow agreement) together with an additional amount of cash or cash equivalents in an amount that, when taken together with the rights to receive any cash or cash equivalents under one or more letters of credit or Sponsor Escrow Interest Commitment Letters (as defined below), would equal the amount of interest that would accrue on the notes to, but excluding, July 31, 2023. If neither the Release Date nor a special mandatory redemption has previously occurred, no later than three business days prior to the end of each month (commencing July 31, 2023) and subject to the immediately succeeding sentence, the Issuer will deposit (or cause to be deposited) in the escrow account an additional amount of cash or cash equivalents equal to the interest that would accrue on the notes to, but excluding, the last day of the next succeeding month. At the Issuer’s option, funds managed by affiliates or certain investment affiliates of the Sponsor will (i) enter into equity commitment letters pursuant to which they will, among other things, agree to contribute cash or cash equivalents directly or indirectly to the Issuer in an amount equal to all or a portion of the accrued and unpaid interest on the notes until the special mandatory redemption date in the event that the special mandatory redemption date occurs (each, a “Sponsor Escrow Interest Commitment Letter” and, collectively, the “Sponsor Escrow Interest Commitment Letters”) and/or (ii) in lieu of all or a portion of such amount, deposit or cause to be deposited in the escrow account an amount of cash and/or cash equivalents (either in the form of cash or letters of credit). The Sponsor Escrow Interest Commitment Letters, if applicable, will automatically terminate on the earliest to occur of (x) the completion of the special mandatory redemption and (y) the date of satisfaction of the Escrow Conditions (as described below). Upon delivery to the escrow agent and the Trustee of an officer’s certificate instructing the escrow agent to release the escrowed funds and certifying that prior to or substantially concurrently with the release of funds from escrow to us (i) the Merger will be consummated in all material respects as described above, (ii) the Credit Facilities will be entered into and (iii) the Equity Contribution (as defined below) will be made in an aggregate amount sufficient, when taken together with the escrowed funds, borrowings available under the Credit Facilities and cash and cash equivalents of Univar, to consummate the Merger and to pay fees and expenses in connection therewith (collectively, the “Escrow Conditions”), the escrowed funds will be released to the Issuer. See “Description of Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.” In addition, if the Escrow Conditions are satisfied, a deferred discount will be paid to the initial purchasers in connection with this offering. If the Escrow Conditions are not satisfied on or prior to January 31, 2024 or such earlier date as the Issuer determines in its sole discretion that the Escrow Conditions cannot be satisfied or the Issuer notifies the escrow agent and the Trustee in writing that the Issuer will not pursue the consummation of the Merger and/or the Merger Agreement is validly terminated (such earliest date, the “Escrow Termination Date”), the Issuer will be required to redeem the notes no later than five business days thereafter at a price equal to 100% of the issue price of the notes, together with accrued and unpaid interest on the notes, if any, to, but excluding, the date of such special mandatory redemption. Escrowed funds would be released and applied to pay for any such redemption. See “Description of Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.” If the issuance of the notes occurs on the Merger Closing Date, none of the escrow provisions described in this offering memorandum will be applicable, no proceeds of this offering will be deposited into the escrow account and all such proceeds will be provided to the Issuer on the issue date for use as described under “Use of Proceeds.” 18 ----- At or prior to the closing of the Merger, funds affiliated with or controlled by our Sponsor and certain coinvestors will directly or indirectly contribute an aggregate amount of approximately $3,727.9 million in cash (which amount may be increased or decreased depending on the final amount of cash of Univar designated by Parent to be used to fund a portion of the Merger consideration, the amount of fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions and the actual amount of cash to be received upon the termination of interest rate and cross currency swaps) in the form of equity to Parent, which amount will be indirectly contributed to the Issuer in the form of common equity and used to fund a portion of the Transactions and to pay related fees and expenses. We refer to this cash equity contribution as the “Equity Contribution.” Concurrently with the closing of the Merger, we will enter into a credit agreement governing the five-year $1,400.0 million senior secured asset-based revolving credit facility (the “ABL Facility”), $500.0 million of which we expect to be drawn at the closing of the Merger, and a credit agreement governing the seven-year $2,300.0 million (equivalent) senior secured first lien term loan facility, comprised of a $1,750.0 million U.S. dollar tranche and a $550.0 million (equivalent) euro tranche (the “Term Loan Facility” and, together with the ABL Facility, the “Credit Facilities”). See “Description of Other Indebtedness” for a description of the Credit Facilities. Univar intends to issue a conditional notice of redemption to redeem all $454.0 million of its outstanding 5.125% Senior Notes due 2027 (the “Existing Notes”) on the Merger Closing Date at a redemption price equal to 102.563% of the principal amount of the Existing Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. To the extent that the redemption does not occur on the Merger Closing Date, Univar expects to satisfy and discharge its obligations under the Existing Notes, and the governing indenture, on the Merger Closing Date by depositing with the trustee under such indenture funds sufficient to pay the applicable redemption price for the Existing Notes, including all accrued and unpaid interest, on the scheduled redemption date. In connection with the Merger, any outstanding borrowings under Univar’s existing term loan credit facilities and asset-based revolving credit facilities (the “Existing Facilities”) will be repaid and the commitments thereunder will be terminated. Throughout this offering memorandum, we refer to the Merger, the Equity Contribution, the entry into, and borrowings under, the ABL Facility and the Term Loan Facility, the redemption of Univar’s outstanding Existing Notes (including any related satisfaction and discharge), the repayment of the Existing Facilities and the termination of the commitments thereunder, the consummation of this offering and, in each case, the use of proceeds thereof, collectively, as the “Transactions.”

We intend to use the proceeds from the issuance of the notes, together with borrowings under the Credit Facilities, the Equity Contribution and cash from the balance sheet of Univar, to fund the Transactions and to pay related fees and expenses. The following table sets forth the estimated sources and uses of funds in connection with the Transactions, assuming they occurred on March 31, 2023 and based on estimated amounts outstanding on that date. The actual sources and uses of funds may vary from the estimated sources and uses of funds set forth below. The estimated sources and uses of funds presented below should be read in conjunction with “—The Transactions,” “Use of Proceeds,” “Capitalization” and “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Data” included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. 19 -----

The final redemption price will also include accrued and unpaid interest from June 1, 2023 to, but excluding, the 20 ----- redemption date, which is not included in the amount set forth above. The final redemption price will vary based on the date of redemption and accrued and unpaid interest on the Existing Notes to the date of redemption. See “—The Transactions.” (9) As of March 31, 2023, there was approximately $1,979.5 million outstanding under Univar’s Existing Facilities, which will be repaid in full and terminated concurrently with the consummation of the Merger. (10) Represents estimated transaction fees and expenses of approximately $438.0 million. Estimated transaction fees and expenses include costs associated with the financing and other transactional fees and expenses, including legal, accounting and other professional fees. Certain of the initial purchasers and/or their respective affiliates are lenders under Univar’s Existing Facilities, holders of the Existing Notes and/or holders of Univar’s common stock and therefore will receive a portion of the gross proceeds of the notes offered hereby. In addition, certain of the initial purchasers and/or their respective affiliates will be lenders, agents and/or arrangers under the Credit Facilities and will receive customary compensation in connection therewith, and have, from time to time, performed various commercial and investment banking and financial advisory services for us. Furthermore, J.P. Morgan Chase Bank, N.A., an affiliate of J.P. Morgan Securities LLC, is acting as Escrow Agent in connection with the Transactions and will receive customary compensation in connection therewith. Apollo Global Securities, LLC is an affiliate of Apollo, our Sponsor, and will receive a portion of the gross spread as an initial purchaser in the sale of the notes offered hereby. See “Plan of Distribution” for more details.

The diagram below sets forth a simplified version of our organizational structure and our principal indebtedness after the completion of the Transactions. This chart is provided for illustrative purposes only and does not represent all legal entities affiliated with, or all obligations of, the Issuer. 21 ----- (1) Holdings will guarantee the ABL Facility and the Term Loan Facility on a limited recourse basis but will not guarantee the notes. In addition, Holdings will pledge all of the equity interests it directly holds of the Issuer to secure the Term Loan Facility on a first-priority basis and the ABL Facility on a second-priority basis. The equity interests of the Issuer held by Holdings will not secure the notes. (2) As of the closing date of the Transactions, the Issuer will pledge substantially all of its material owned assets, other than the ABL Priority Collateral and subject to certain exceptions (the “Notes Priority Collateral”), as collateral for the Term Loan Facility and the notes on a first-priority basis and for the ABL Facility on a second-priority basis. The Issuer will pledge substantially all of its inventory and accounts receivable and related assets, subject to certain exceptions (the “ABL Priority Collateral”), as collateral for the ABL Facility on a first-priority basis and for the Term Loan Facility and the notes on a second-priority basis. See “Description of Other Indebtedness.” (3) As of the closing of the Transactions, we expect that approximately $500.0 million will be drawn and outstanding under the ABL Facility. Based on estimated borrowing base availability of approximately $1,307.2 million as of March 31, 2023, approximately $500.0 million expected to be drawn as of the closing date and approximately $129.3 million of letters of credit expected to be outstanding as of the closing date, we would have had approximately $677.9 million of borrowings available under the ABL Facility as of March 31, 2023 on a pro forma basis after giving effect to the Transactions. See “Description of Other Indebtedness” for a description of the ABL Facility. (4)  At the effective time of the Merger, Merger Sub will merge with and into Univar, with Univar surviving the Merger as a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Issuer. 22 ----- (5) As of the closing date of the Transactions, all wholly-owned material domestic subsidiaries of the Issuer (other than domestic subsidiaries that are subsidiaries of foreign subsidiaries), including Univar, will guarantee the Credit Facilities and the notes. In addition, all such subsidiary guarantors will pledge substantially all of their material owned assets, other than ABL Priority Collateral, subject to certain exceptions (the “Notes Priority Collateral”), as collateral for the Term Loan Facility and the notes on a first-priority basis and for the ABL Facility on a second-priority basis. The subsidiary guarantors will pledge substantially all of their inventory and accounts receivable and related assets, subject to certain exceptions (the “ABL Priority Collateral”), as collateral for the ABL Facility on a first-priority basis and for the Term Loan Facility and the notes on a second-priority basis. See “Description of Other Indebtedness” and “Description of Notes.” (6) Non-guarantor subsidiaries consist of non-wholly owned subsidiaries, foreign subsidiaries (and domestic subsidiaries that are subsidiaries of foreign subsidiaries) and certain other subsidiaries. As of March 31, 2023, our non-guarantor subsidiaries held approximately 36% of our consolidated assets and during the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, our non-guarantor subsidiaries generated approximately 34% of our total revenues and approximately 34% of our Reported Adjusted EBITDA. As of March 31, 2023, our non-guarantor subsidiaries had approximately $387.0 million of outstanding indebtedness, excluding intercompany obligations. Certain foreign subsidiaries will be obligors under the ABL Facility but will not guarantee the Term Loan Facility or the notes.

Apollo is a high-growth, global alternative asset manager. In Apollo’s asset management business, Apollo seeks to provide its clients excess return at every point along the risk-reward spectrum from investment grade to private equity with a focus on three investing strategies: yield, hybrid, and equity. For more than three decades, Apollo’s investing expertise across its fully integrated platform has served the financial return needs of its clients and provided businesses with innovative capital solutions for growth. Through Athene, Apollo’s retirement services business, Apollo specializes in helping clients achieve financial security by providing a suite of retirement savings products and acting as a solutions provider to institutions. Apollo’s patient, creative, and knowledgeable approach to investing aligns its clients, businesses it invests in, its employees, and the communities it impacts, to expand opportunity and achieve positive outcomes. As of March 31, 2023, Apollo had approximately $598 billion of assets under management.
Our principal executive offices are located at 3075 Highland Pkwy Ste 200, Downers Grove, IL 60515. Our telephone number is (331) 777-6000. 23 -----

The Sponsor Escrow Interest Commitment Letters, if applicable, will automatically terminate on the earliest to occur of (x) the completion of the special mandatory redemption and (y) the date of satisfaction of the Escrow Conditions.
