Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: INDUSTRY The Chemical and Ingredient Distribution Industry
Subsubsection Text: Distributors play an essential role within the global chemical value chain by providing customers of all sizes access to mission-critical chemicals and ingredients that underpin their commercial products. While suppliers are able to directly serve large end-users, there are many thousands of smaller customers who require chemical and ingredient inputs that are not economic for large producers to serve. Distributors fill this gap by purchasing chemicals and ingredients from producers worldwide to warehouse, repackage, blend, dilute, transport, and sell those chemicals to customers through a more regional supply chain and at volumes that may be meaningfully below traditional order sizes for producers. Chemical and ingredient producers rely on distributors to market and sell their products – to expand their industry access, enhance their geographic reach, lower their cost to serve, and grow their business. Distributors may also offer additional services like formulation, technical and engineering consulting, digital insights, and guidance around regulations. At the same time, customers that purchase through distribution benefit from a lower total cost of ownership and simplify their chemical and ingredient sourcing process with benefits including just-in- time delivery, excellent product availability and selection, packaging, mixing, blending, and technical expertise. There are many factors that can influence customer preference when evaluating which distributor(s) to partner with, including: - **Scale and logistics network – Locality and network breadth to ensure chemicals can be received quickly and at volume. Proximity to customers also drives engagement and enables logistical flexibility for the distributor; - **Availability of a broad range of products – Access to a sizeable portfolio and inventory of chemicals that can meet all of the customer’s needs and are available when such needs arise. A broad portfolio allows customers to source from a single distributor, simplifying operations and lowering costs; - **Technical expertise and service – Customer centricity and strong chemical and ingredient know how – including the ability to jointly innovate with customers and match their needs and capabilities to the required chemical and ingredient inputs, particularly for smaller customers who may not have internal technical resources; and - **Quality of supplier and brands – Partnership with leading producers to ensure a consistent and reliable supply of chemical product, primarily sourced within the geographies of the customer to ensure security of supply. 139 ----- At the same time, suppliers are seeking distributors who demonstrate the following: - **Scale and extensive logistics network – Strong presence in regions where suppliers’ products are in demand, as well as strong logistics capabilities to handle transportation, storage and delivery of products across a wide range of products and volumes; - **Technical expertise and market knowledge – A deep understanding of both products being distributed, as well as markets being served (including key players, trends and regulatory requirements) to provide insights and analysis to suppliers; - **Financial stability – A solid financial track record and strong creditworthiness to ensure shipments are paid on time and consistent investments are made in the business over the long-term; - **Brand awareness – Reputable track record in distribution to support suppliers’ own brand recognition and perception of quality in the market; and - **Digital as a trend – Advanced digital capabilities to provide insights into customer behavior, which can then be used to strengthen both the producer and the distributor’s positions within a given market.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Commodity chemical distributors focus on standardized chemicals that have minimal variation per application. Commodity chemicals are often used as the starting material to produce a wide variety of other chemicals and tend to have transparent pricing, with producers typically selling large volumes to their customers. Examples of commodity chemicals include ethylene, propylene, phenol, methanol, and formaldehyde. The Univar Solutions product portfolio principally includes a wide range of organic and inorganic chemistries, surfactants, inorganic compounds and general chemicals which are used extensively throughout most end markets. For these commodity chemical distributors, product availability, logistical network and customer service are essential differentiators for customers, given the limited potential for product differentiation. For suppliers, scale, reliability and reputation are key success factors when selecting a distributor. Suppliers favor commodity chemical 140 ----- distributors with broad logistical networks and a suitable inventory across a comprehensive product portfolio, particularly if they are able to enable expansion beyond that supplier’s existing offering (either via incremental endmarkets or new geographic markets). The ability to purchase higher volumes is also attractive for suppliers, who thus favor larger-scale commodity chemical distributors in order to reach smaller, more regionalized customers. Additionally, greater scale gives us better insight into market trends, generating a better understanding of real-time demands of customers, greater market insights, and a higher level of technical expertise. Switching costs are however low for suppliers, and relationships are generally not exclusive. Given the commodity focused nature, these distributors typically operate lower-margin, higher-volume business models, relative to other distributors. However, given the relatively low cost of commodity chemicals, these products make up a limited portion of a customer’s total costs, and as a result, customers tend to be inclined to maintain relationships with their distributors if products are delivered safely and on-time. Despite selling relatively standardized products, commodity chemical distributors vary significantly to chemical traders. The trader business model is predicated largely on the purchase and sale of bulk chemicals, given the relatively transparent pricing and spot markets. While commodity chemical distributors also generate value through their ability to maintain a spread between purchase and selling price, they differ greatly given their intense customer focus and value-additive service offering embedded within their business model. Commodity chemical distributors maintain a highly complex logistical network to ensure that customers are able to receive their products in a timely manner, given their mission critical status to most operations. At the same time, these chemicals are often hazardous and difficult-to-handle, adding an additional layer of complexity that distributors manage for both suppliers and customers.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Specialty chemical distributors focus on complex and tailored formulations that target specific applications within a given end market. Specialty chemical pricing is based on the value added by the product and is generally sold by a skilled and technical salesforce that is able to create or recommend customized formulations for their end customers. Specialty chemical distributors operate on a lower-volume, higher-margin model. While less capital-intensive than commodity chemicals, scale remains vital in specialty chemical distributors, as it allows companies to leverage a larger product portfolio to gain more touch points across suppliers and customers. Sometimes, less technical logistical and warehousing operations are outsourced to third parties, while technical marketing and business development are crucial activities performed in-house. Examples of categories of specialty chemicals include construction chemicals, adhesives, food additives, and surfactants. In their production, specialty chemicals undergo a complicated value chain. They generally begin as commodity chemicals, which are essentially used as raw materials that undergo reactions to form chemical intermediates. From there, specific chemical or biological reactions are performed to further refine these intermediates into specialty chemicals and ingredients. Oftentimes, several reactions and processes must be performed to create a specific specialty product. Due to the complexity of this value chain, specialty chemicals are generally sold as downstream products and tailored for niche end markets. For specialty distributors, domain expertise in a given end market is essential, alongside the ability to create tailor-made solutions for customers. To this end, supplier relationships are essential and often exist on an exclusive basis. Thus, switching costs are generally high, and specialty chemicals are not easily replaceable with one another in comparison to commodity chemicals, particularly to smaller customers for whom custom formulations have been prepared.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Full-line distributors encompass both commodity and specialty products to provide end-to-end chemical solutions to customers. This model is pursued by large global players with scale, such as Univar Solutions and Brenntag, to enable a sophisticated business model that can effectively serve both commodity and specialty customers despite their contrasting needs. Our commodity channel is reported as C&S. The C&S channel is characterized by two core competencies: Local Chemical Distribution (“LCD”) and Bulk Chemical Distribution (“BCD”). In LCD, we are the largest while 141 ----- having a strong local presence as a distributor throughout the United States and Canada with the most extensive network and facility capabilities. We are able to receive product in barge, rail and truck and deliver to our customers by rail, truck and parcel, outlining the extent of our reach. In BCD, we are a market leader in the United States and Canada for six major inorganic chemistries. We are able to demonstrate producer-like economies of scale with distributor level logistics. The C&S channel also offers differentiating services like MiniBulk, a high retention, safe, full-service model for difficult-to-handle chemicals, and ChemCare, a waste chemical collection and disposal service. Due to the capital-intensive nature of commodity distribution, our expansive scale offers numerous advantages including its denser logistics network, broad stock availability, competitive pricing, and deeper supplier and customer relationships. Our specialty channel is reported as I&S. I&S is powered by dedicated sales, marketing, product management and technical services dedicated to each end market we serve. Additionally, our global network of solution centers focused on product formulation, technical differentiation, and problem solving. Despite the specialty chemical and ingredient distribution channel being less capital-intensive by nature, our large scale still proves to be advantageous, as its scale provides its customers with access to a stronger product portfolio, supply assurance, technical expertise, and a broader range of value-added services that are essential and often don’t exist inhouse. For full-line distributors including Univar Solutions, there are synergies between operating both business models. The critical size in storage and logistics required for the commodity channel supports the specialty channel by enabling a broader product suite to be supported by a distribution infrastructure enabling effective logistics to clients. Overall, the full-line distributor model can take advantage of industry growth trends across a range of end markets and maintain diversification and stability, thus lowering overall business volatility.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: There are three primary chemical distribution business models – commodity, specialty, and “full-line” – which each have their own distinct characteristics.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The chemical distribution market is highly fragmented due to the diverse range of products, services, customers, and its regionalized nature (smaller distributors generally specialize in particular regions as well as products). While the industry consists of tens of thousands of players, scaled distributors have some competitive advantages due to their existing capital investment, significant logistics networks and experience operating in a highly regulated environment.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: North American Chemical Distribution Competitive Landscape[(a)]
Subsubsection Text: (a) Source: ICIS Top 100 Chemical Distributors 142 ----- The fragmented market provides an opportunity for larger players to consolidate in specific channels, products and regions. Customers generally seek a “one-stop shop” distributor with strong industry knowledge, multiple product lines, and various geographic regions and end markets served. Likewise, suppliers prefer to work with fewer distributors in order to reduce costs and complexities that arise from dealing with multiple distributors. The key drivers for market consolidation include: - **Building scale in existing geographies and channels and broadening geographic reach – Distributors seek to capture a higher number of customers in both their existing geographies, as well as in new markets. In turn, this benefits suppliers who also seek a broader distribution network for their products, particularly in geographies that it is not economical or practical for them to serve directly; - **Bolt-on acquisitions – Distributors acquire local or regional distributors that service suppliers with whom they already have a strong relationship within other geographies, both to reduce complexity and to create a “one-stop shop” for the supplier. These acquisitions are generally performed to strengthen supplier-distributor relationships; - **Greater efficiency and ease of business for customers – Distributors consolidate with the goal of channel expansion by acquiring smaller companies to improve supplier relationships and product mix. This strengthens the value proposition for customers that seek large distributors with a broad product portfolio; - **Vertical integration – Both acquisitions of upstream or downstream companies in the chemical value chain allow distributors to expand capabilities, reduce risk of supply chain disruptions and capture a larger portion of the total value transferred and added; and - **Increased capabilities and value-added services – New services strengthen the distributor's value proposition for both customers and suppliers that seek market expertise and value-added services. (e.g., our acquisition of Nexeo in 2019, which added important technology including new ERP and pricing tools, as well as strengthened operating capabilities, especially in our I&S channel).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: As of 2022, the estimated market for chemical consumption is approximately $4,800 billion, of which approximately $1,500 billion of considered non-distributable (e.g., products that travel to customers through pipelines), resulting in a market for distributable chemical consumption of approximately $3,300 billion. Within this market, it is estimated that only 11% is currently served through distributors globally. The outsourced chemical distribution market in 2022 was approximately $320 billion in size, and is expected to return to stable long-term real growth of 3-5% following recent supply chain disruptions. The market consistently shows steady growth across both commodity and specialty sectors, as well as across geographies. 143 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Global Chemicals Distribution Industry (ex. Asia) and End Markets [(a)]
Subsubsection Text: Though the global chemical and ingredient distribution industry is large and highly fragmented, it still represents a relatively small portion of total available chemical industry sales. The chemical industry as a whole is projected to grow close to gross national product (“GNP”) of countries operated in around the world, while the distributed chemicals portion of the industry is projected to grow even faster, as its fullest potential has not yet been realized. Global chemical consumption is predicted to grow at approximately 2-4% annually into the long-term.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Global Chemicals Distribution Industry (ex. Asia) and End Markets [(a)]
Subsubsection Text: Currently, only approximately 11% of the Chemical Distribution market is outsourced to chemical distributors. Due to regulation, increased focus on sustainability, digitization, regionalization, and globalization of supply, outsourcing is expected to increase by 10bps per year, driving approximately 1% of incremental Chemical Distribution market growth annually. Many suppliers turn to third-party distributors to manage supply-chain operations. This ensures that suppliers can focus on core capabilities such as manufacturing and R&D, while allowing distributors to focus on sales and complexity issues beyond suppliers’ expertise. Outsourcing penetration in specialty chemicals is lower than that of commodities due to the more specialized production techniques, greater demands in product handling and transportation, increased technical expertise needed to sell specialty products and the more niche end market applications. 144 ----- There are a number of trends supporting a longer-term increase in outsourcing to chemical distributors in the medium to long- term: - Suppliers seeking to reduce complexity by transferring smaller customers to distributors and consolidating distribution channels (benefiting large and scaled distributors); - As customer differentiation increases, higher complexity within smaller customer channels arises, which is easier for distributors to manage; - Customers seeking increased value-added services and formulation support with digital technology capabilities, which distributors are continuing to invest in; - Geographic reach in growth markets, such as Asia-Pacific, Africa, and Latin America, where distributors have better access; and - Increasing regulatory requirements in developed markets (including increased focus on ESG) and demand for compliance in emerging markets that a distributor is better suited to handle and more experienced in. Based on our survey of suppliers, over 75% of suppliers expect both specialty and commodity outsourcing in North America, Europe and APAC to grow over the next three years. Supplier expectations for outsourcing penetration vary by channel and region. In Europe, 86% of suppliers expect growth in specialty, while 94% expect growth in commodity. In North America, 83% of suppliers expect growth in specialty, while only 76% expect growth in commodity. Overall, suppliers expect North American chemical distribution outsourcing penetration to reach approximately 22-23% by 2027 while in Europe, it is expected to reach approximately 12% by 2027. Every 10bps increase in yearly outsourcing rate from 2022 to 2028 is expected to drive an additional approximately 0.8% of market CAGR for chemical distribution.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Global Chemicals Distribution Industry (ex. Asia) and End Markets [(a)]
Subsubsection Text: Overall, the distributor model is more resilient to recessionary periods than chemical production and the model provides a natural cash flow hedge in a downturn since working capital unwinds when revenue contracts. Generally, there are a number of factors that support resiliency in chemical distribution in recessionary periods: - **Customer diversification – Given the highly fragmented customer-base of the business, oftentimes 145 ----- distributors are not reliant on a few main customers for sales; - **Geographic diversification – Global distributors will experience lessened impacts of regional geopolitical events and can manage supply chains accordingly in the event of a slowdown in a particular region; - **Resilient end market exposure – Exposure to life sciences end markets like personal care, healthcare, food nutrients, and pharmaceuticals, are less cyclical. Demand in these end markets remain strong, even in a poor economy; and - **Flexible asset-light business model – Despite warehouses and trucks being an integral part of chemical distribution, many distributors choose to outsource this task. Chemical distributors also provide asset-light offerings including strong relationships between suppliers and customers, industry expertise and technical capabilities. 146 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Global Chemicals Distribution Industry (ex. Asia) and End Markets [(a)]
Subsubsection Text: (a) Source: IHS, Remakers. Oxford Economics, internal data and management views Since 2015, the distribution market has grown steadily at approximately 3-5% year over year. From 20192022, the market experienced little disruption from COVID-19 and growth of approximately 4-5%, underpinned by increased pricing driven by supply chain constraints during the COVID-19 period. In 2023, the market is expected to experience a year of price normalization, in which slower growth of approximately 2% is expected. From 20232027, the overall market is expected to grow at approximately 4-5% however there is variation across end markets including Food and Pharma which are expected to grow at rates greater than 5%. Growth is expected to be driven by both the following factors:

Unless otherwise indicated or the context otherwise requires, references in this management’s discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations to “we,” “our,” “us” and “the Company” refer to Univar and its consolidated subsidiaries before giving effect to the consummation of the Transactions._

Section Title: SECURITY OWNERSHIP OF CERTAIN BENEFICIAL OWNERS AND MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Text: Upon the consummation of the Transactions, all of the Issuer’s issued and outstanding equity interests will be held by Holdings and all of Holdings’ issued and outstanding equity interests will be directly or indirectly owned by Parent. At such time, funds affiliated with our Sponsor, ADIA and certain co-investors are expected to collectively beneficially own all of the outstanding equity interests of Parent. All of our directors that are affiliated with our Sponsor may be deemed to beneficially own equity interests beneficially owned by our Sponsor. Each such individual disclaims beneficial ownership of any such equity interests in which such individual does not have a pecuniary interest. In addition, it is currently contemplated that certain employees will receive options or profits interests in Parent as further described under “Management—Equity Compensation Awards.” 149 -----

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the Transactions, an affiliate of our Sponsor will enter into a transaction fee agreement with the Issuer relating to the provision of certain preparation services in support of the Transactions and future acquisitions or similar transactions following the Transactions. In exchange for the provision of the services, the Issuer will pay (a) a non-refundable fee to an affiliate of our Sponsor upon the consummation of the Transactions and (b) in the event of any acquisition (including of assets or equity interests) of any business or entity by any of the Issuer, its direct or indirect subsidiaries, parent entities or controlled affiliates (collectively, the “Issuer Group”), a fee of up to 1% of the aggregate enterprise value paid by the Issuer Group or otherwise indicated by the acquisition to such affiliate of our Sponsor. Upon the consummation of the Transactions, the Issuer will make payments of approximately $84 million to our affiliates.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS

The management consulting agreement will provide that, in exchange for these services, the Issuer will pay an annual management fee of $10.0 million, payable quarterly to such affiliate of our Sponsor.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: The following discussion reflects our relationships and related party transactions entered into in connection with the Transactions.

We plan to enter into a new $2,300.0 million (equivalent) senior secured term loan credit facility (the “Term Loan Facility”), comprised of a $1,750 million U.S. dollar tranche (the “USD Term Loans”) and a $550.0 million (equivalent) euro tranche (the “Euro Term Loans”), on the closing date of the Merger. The Term Loan Facility is expected to have a maturity of seven years. In addition, we may request one or more incremental term loan facilities, one or more incremental revolving credit facilities and/or an increase in commitments under the Term Loan Facility (collectively, “incremental facilities”) in an aggregate amount of up to the sum of (x) the greater of (i) $965.0 million and (ii) 1.00 times Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA calculated on a pro forma basis as of the date of incurrence of such incremental facilities or the establishment of commitments in respect thereof plus (y) such additional amounts so long as, (i) in the case of loans under incremental facilities secured by liens on the collateral that rank pari passu with the liens on collateral securing the Term Loan Facility, our net first lien secured leverage ratio calculated on a pro forma basis would be no greater than a ratio to be agreed upon, (ii) in the case of loans under incremental facilities secured by liens on collateral that rank junior to the liens on the collateral securing the Term Loan Facility, our net secured leverage ratio calculated on a pro forma basis would be no greater than a ratio to be agreed upon and (iii) in the case of loans under such incremental facilities that are unsecured, either (1) the ratio of Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA to total cash interest expense calculated on a pro forma basis is not less than 2.00 to 1.00 or (2) our net total leverage ratio would be no greater than a ratio to be agreed upon, in each case, subject to certain conditions and receipt of commitments by existing or additional lenders plus (z) available capacity under a general debt basket to be agreed upon. Proceeds of the term loans drawn on the closing date of the Merger, together with the other sources of funds described under “Use of Proceeds,” will be used to partially fund the Transactions and to pay related fees and expenses.

Borrowings under the Term Loan Facility will bear interest at a rate equal to, (x) in the case of Euro Term Loans, EURIBOR determined by reference to the interbank offered rate administered by the European Money Markets Institute, adjusted for certain additional costs, which rate shall be no less than a floor to be agreed (“Adjusted EURIBOR”) or (y) in the case of the USD Term Loans, at our option, either (a) term SOFR determined by reference to the secured overnight financing rate published by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which rate shall be no less than zero or (b) a base rate determined by reference to the highest of (i) the sum of the federal funds rate plus 0.50% per annum, (ii) the prime rate quoted by The Wall Street Journal as the “Prime Rate” and (iii) the sum of one-month term SOFR plus 1.00% per annum, plus, for each of term SOFR, Adjusted EURIBOR and the base rate, an applicable margin to be agreed upon.

The USD Term Loans will require scheduled quarterly amortization payments of USD Term Loans in an annual amount equal to 1.0% of the original principal amount of the USD Term Loans borrowed on the closing date 151 ----- of the Term Loan Facility, with the balance to be paid at maturity. The Euro Term Loans will not amortize and the aggregate principal amount of the Euro Term Loans will be paid at maturity. In addition, the Term Loan Facility will require us to prepay outstanding term loan borrowings, subject to certain exceptions, with: - beginning with the first full fiscal year ending after the closing date of the Term Loan Facility, 50% (which percentage will be reduced to 25% and 0% if the net first lien secured leverage ratio is less than or equal to ratios to be agreed upon) of our annual excess cash flow, as defined under the Term Loan Facility; - 100% (which percentage will be reduced to 50% and 0% if the net first lien secured leverage ratio is less than or equal to ratios to be agreed upon) of the net cash proceeds of all non-ordinary course asset sales, other dispositions of property or certain casualty events, in each case subject to certain exceptions and reinvestment rights; and - 100% of the net cash proceeds of any issuance or incurrence of debt, other than proceeds from debt permitted under the Term Loan Facility. We may voluntarily repay outstanding loans under the Term Loan Facility at any time, without prepayment premium or penalty, except in connection with a repricing event in respect of the term loans as described below, subject to customary “breakage” costs with respect to loans bearing interest at term SOFR or Adjusted EURIBOR. Any refinancing through the issuance of certain debt or any repricing amendment, in either case, that constitutes a “repricing event” applicable to the term loans resulting in a lower yield occurring at any time during the first six months after the closing date of the Term Loan Facility will be accompanied by a 1.00% prepayment premium or fee, as applicable.

All obligations under the Term Loan Facility will be unconditionally guaranteed by Holdings on a limitedrecourse basis and by each of our existing and future direct and indirect, wholly owned material domestic subsidiaries, subject to certain exceptions. The obligations under the Term Loan Facility will be secured by a pledge of our capital stock directly held by Holdings and by the same priority liens on the assets of the Issuer and the subsidiary guarantors that secure the notes, as further described in the section entitled “Description of Notes— Security.”

The Term Loan Facility will contain certain customary affirmative covenants. The negative covenants in the Term Loan Facility will include, among other things, limitations (none of which are absolute) on our ability to: - incur additional debt or issue certain preferred shares; - create liens on certain assets; - make certain loans or investments (including acquisitions); - pay dividends on or make distributions in respect of our capital stock or make other restricted payments; - consolidate, amalgamate, merge, sell or otherwise dispose of all or substantially all of our assets; - sell certain assets; 152 ----- - enter into certain transactions with our affiliates; - enter into certain sale-leaseback transactions; - change our lines of business; - restrict dividends from our subsidiaries or restrict liens; - change our fiscal year; and - prepay subordinated debt or modify the terms of certain debt or organizational agreements. The Term Loan Facility will contain a customary passive holding company covenant with respect to Holdings. The Term Loan Facility will contain certain customary events of default, including relating to a change of control. If an event of default occurs, the lenders under the Term Loan Facility will be entitled to take various actions, including the acceleration of amounts due under the Term Loan Facility and all actions permitted to be taken by a secured creditor in respect of the collateral securing the Term Loan Facility.

We plan to enter into a new senior secured asset-based revolving credit facility (the “ABL Facility”) on the closing date of the Merger, which we expect will provide aggregate borrowing availability equal to the lesser of $1,400.0 million (equivalent) and the borrowing base described below. The ABL Facility is expected to have a maturity of five years. On the Merger Closing Date, the ABL Facility is expected to have two subfacilities, consisting of: - a $1,250.0 million subfacility with respect to borrowings by borrowers organized in the United States or Canada (the “North American ABL Subfacility”); and - a $150.0 million (equivalent) subfacility with respect to borrowings by borrowers organized in certain European jurisdictions set forth in the definitive documentation for the ABL Facility (the “European ABL Subfacility”). Borrowing availability under the North American ABL Subfacility will be determined based on the North American borrowing base described below. Borrowing availability under the European ABL Subfacility will be determined based on the European borrowing base described below. In addition, we may request one or more “first-in-last-out” incremental revolving credit facilities and/or increases in commitments under the ABL Facility in an aggregate amount not to exceed the greater of (x) the greater of 1.00 times Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA calculated on a pro forma basis and $965.0 million and (y) the amount by which the then-current borrowing base exceeds total commitments under the ABL Facility, in each case, subject to certain conditions and receipt of commitments by existing or additional lenders. We may also request additional incremental revolving credit facilities with respect to borrowers organized in certain non-U.S. jurisdictions, subject to certain terms and conditions. All borrowings under the ABL Facility following the closing date of the Merger will be subject to the satisfaction of customary conditions, including the absence of a default or event of default and the accuracy of representations and warranties in all material respects. Proceeds of the loans under the ABL Facility drawn on the closing date of the Merger, together with the other sources of funds described under “Use of Proceeds,” will be used to partially fund the Transactions (subject to 153 ----- a cap on the amount that may be borrowed on the closing date of the Merger). Proceeds of the loans under the ABL Facility drawn after the closing date of the Merger, swingline loans and letters of credit will be used for working capital and general corporate purposes. We expect that $500.0 million under the ABL Facility will be drawn on the closing date of the Merger (in addition to approximately $129.3 million of letters of credit expected to be outstanding as of the closing date).

The North American borrowing base under the North American ABL Subfacility will be, at any time of determination, an amount (net of reserves) equal to, with respect to the Issuer and the subsidiary borrowers and subsidiary guarantors organized in the United States or Canada, the sum of: - 85% of the book value of eligible receivables (other than receivables from investment grade account debtors), plus - 90% of the net appraised liquidation value of eligible inventory, plus - 90% of the book value of eligible receivables from investment grade account debtors, plus - 100% of qualified cash of North American loan parties (provided, that, the aggregate amount of qualified cash included in the North American borrowing base will not exceed 15% of the North American borrowing base). The European borrowing base under the European ABL Subfacility will be, at any time of determination, an amount (net of reserves) equal to, with respect to the subsidiary borrowers and subsidiary guarantors organized in certain European jurisdictions set forth in the definitive documentation for the ABL Facility, the sum of: - 85% of the book value of eligible receivables (other than receivables from investment grade account debtors), plus - 85% of the net appraised liquidation value of eligible inventory, plus - 90% of eligible investment grade receivables, _provided that the amount of eligible receivables and eligible inventory attributable to borrowers organized in certain_ non-U.S. jurisdictions shall not exceed a sublimit to be agreed. The ABL Facility is expected to include provisions allowing reallocation of commitments among the North American ABL Subfacility, the European ABL Subfacility and certain subfacilities that may be established with respect to borrowers organized in certain non-U.S. jurisdictions, subject to certain terms and conditions. The ABL Facility is expected to include borrowing capacity available for letters of credit and bank guarantees and for borrowings on same-day notice, referred to as swing line loans. Based on estimated borrowing base availability of approximately $1,307.2 million as of March 31, 2023, approximately $500.0 million expected to be drawn as of the closing date and approximately $129.3 million of letters of credit expected to be outstanding as of the closing date, we would have had approximately $677.9 million of borrowings available under the ABL Facility as of March 31, 2023 on a pro forma basis after giving effect to the Transactions. The estimated borrowing base availability of $1,307.2 million as of March 31, 2023 will be updated based on a field exam and appraisal and therefore could differ as of the closing date of the Transactions.

Borrowings under the ABL Facility will bear interest at a rate equal to (w) with respect to borrowings of US dollars, at our option, either (a) term SOFR determined by reference to the secured overnight financing rate published by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York plus a credit spread adjustment or (b) a base rate determined by reference to the highest of (i) the federal funds rate plus 0.50% per annum, (ii) the prime rate and (iii) the sum of one-month adjusted term SOFR plus 1.00% per annum, (x) with respect to borrowings of Euros, either (a) 154 ----- EURIBOR determined by reference to the interbank offered rate administered by the European Money Markets Institute, adjusted for certain additional costs or (b) in the case of swingline loans funded in Euros, ESTR determined by reference to the Euro Short Term Rate on such business day published by the European Central Bank or (y) with respect to borrowings of pounds sterling, the Daily Simple SONIA determined by reference to the Sterling Overnight Index Average for such business day published by the Bank of England or (z) with respect to borrowings of Canadian dollars, at our option, either (a) the BA Rate determined by reference to the rate for Canadian dollar denominated bankers’ acceptances for the interest period relevant to such borrowing or (b) a prime rate determined by reference to the highest of (i) the prime rate in effect for Canadian dollar denominated commercial loans and (ii) the sum of one-month BA Rate plus 1.00% per annum. Each borrowing will also be subject to the applicable interest rate margin. The applicable margin for SOFR, SONIA, EURIBOR and BA Rate borrowings under the ABL Facility are expected to be 1.50% to 2.00% and the applicable margins for ESTR, base rate and prime rate borrowings under the ABL Facility 0.50% to 1.00%, in each case, based on excess availability. In addition to paying interest on outstanding principal under the ABL Facility, we will be required to pay a commitment fee to the lenders in respect of the unutilized commitments thereunder at a rate equal to 0.25% or 0.375% per annum depending on the average utilization of the commitments. We will also be required to pay customary agency fees as well as letter of credit participation fees computed at a rate per annum equal to the applicable margin for SOFR borrowings (or, in the case of commercial letters of credit, 50% of the applicable margin for SOFR borrowings) on the dollar equivalent of the daily stated amount of outstanding letters of credit, plus such letter of credit issuer’s customary documentary and processing fees and charges and a fronting fee computed at a rate equal to 0.125% per annum on the daily stated amount of each letter of credit. We may voluntarily repay outstanding loans under the ABL Facility at any time, without premium or penalty, subject to customary “breakage” costs with respect to SOFR loans and EURIBOR loans.

All obligations under the ABL Facility (and at our option certain hedging, cash management and bank product obligations secured under the ABL Facility) will be unconditionally guaranteed by Holdings on a limitedrecourse basis and by each of our existing and future direct and indirect, wholly owned domestic material subsidiaries and by certain foreign subsidiaries, subject to certain exceptions. The obligations will be secured by a pledge of our capital stock directly held by Holdings, substantially all of our assets and those of each domestic subsidiary guarantor and by substantially all of the inventory and accounts receivable and related assets of our foreign subsidiary guarantors and foreign subsidiary borrowers, subject to certain exceptions. Such security interest consists of (1) a first-priority lien with respect to the ABL Priority Collateral and (2) a second-priority lien with respect to the Notes Priority Collateral.

The ABL Facility will contain certain customary affirmative covenants. The negative covenants in the ABL Facility will include, among other things, limitations (none of which are absolute) on our ability to: - incur additional debt or issue certain preferred shares; - create liens on certain assets; - make certain loans or investments (including acquisitions); - pay dividends on or make distributions in respect of our capital stock or make other restricted payments; - consolidate, merge, sell or otherwise dispose of all or substantially all of our assets; - sell certain assets; 155 ----- - enter into certain transactions with our affiliates; - enter into certain sale-leaseback transactions; - change our lines of business; - restrict dividends from our subsidiaries or restrict liens; - change our fiscal year; and - prepay subordinated debt or modify the terms of certain debt or organizational agreements. In addition, on or after the last day of the first full fiscal quarter ending after the closing date of the ABL Facility, the ABL Facility will require us to maintain a minimum fixed charge coverage ratio of 1.0 to 1.0 at any time if as of such time availability is less than the greater of (x) $105 million and (y) 10% of the lesser of (i) the borrowing base at such time and (ii) the aggregate amount of ABL Facility commitments at such time. The ABL Facility will contain certain customary events of default, including relating to a change of control. If an event of default occurs, the lenders under the ABL Facility will be entitled to take various actions, including the acceleration of amounts due under the ABL Facility and all actions permitted to be taken by a secured creditor in respect of the collateral securing the ABL Facility. 156 -----

Windsor Holdings III, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company (the “Issuer”), will issue      % Senior Secured Notes due 2030 (the “notes”) under an indenture (the “indenture”), to be entered into by and among the Issuer, the Subsidiary Guarantors (as defined below) party thereto from time to time and Wilmington Trust, National Association, as Trustee. In this description, (i) references to the “Issuer” mean the Issuer, but not any of its Subsidiaries and (ii) “we,” “us” and “our” mean the Issuer and its Subsidiaries. Copies of the indenture (once available) may be obtained from the Issuer upon request. The following summary of certain provisions of the indenture, the notes, the Security Documents, the First Lien Intercreditor Agreement, the ABL Intercreditor Agreement and the Escrow Agreement (as defined below) does not purport to be complete and is subject to, and is qualified in its entirety by reference to, all the provisions of those agreements, including the definitions of certain terms therein. Capitalized terms used in this “Description of Notes” section and not otherwise defined have the meanings set forth in the section “—Certain Definitions.” The Issuer will issue notes with an initial aggregate principal amount of $1,800 million. Following the Issue Date, the Issuer may issue additional notes from time to time. Any offering of additional notes is subject to the covenants described below under the captions “—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Incurrence of Indebtedness and Issuance of Disqualified Stock and Preferred Stock” and “—Certain Covenants—Liens.” The notes and any additional notes subsequently issued under the indenture may, at our election, be treated as a single class for all purposes under the indenture, including, without limitation, waivers, amendments, redemptions and offers to purchase; provided that if the additional notes are not fungible with the notes for U.S. federal income tax purposes, the additional notes will have a separate CUSIP number, if applicable. Unless the context otherwise requires, for all purposes of the indenture and this “Description of Notes,” references to the notes include any additional notes actually issued. This offering may be consummated prior to the Merger Closing Date. If this offering is consummated prior to the Merger Closing Date, the gross proceeds of this offering of the notes will be deposited into the Escrow Account with the Escrow Agent on the Issue Date. The Escrow Agreement is more fully described below under “— Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.” In the event that the Merger Closing Date has not occurred on or before January 31, 2024 (the “Escrow Outside Date”), or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the notes will be redeemed at a price equal to 100% of the issue price of the notes plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the Special Mandatory Redemption Date. See “—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.” If this offering is consummated substantially concurrently with the Merger Closing Date, none of the proceeds of this offering of the notes will be deposited into the Escrow Account with the Escrow Agent and such proceeds will be provided to the Issuer on the Issue Date. Principal of, premium, if any, and interest on the notes will be payable, and the notes may be exchanged or transferred, at the office or agency designated by the Issuer (which initially shall be the designated office or agency of the Trustee). The notes will be issued only in fully registered form, without coupons, in minimum denominations of $2,000 and any integral multiple of $1,000 in excess thereof; provided that notes may be issued in denominations of less than $2,000 solely to accommodate book-entry positions that have been created by a participant of The Depository Trust Company or any successor depositary (“DTC”) in denominations of less than $2,000. No service charge will be made for any registration of transfer or exchange of notes, but the Issuer may require payment of a sum sufficient to cover any transfer tax or other similar governmental charge payable in connection therewith.

The notes will be senior obligations of the Issuer, will have the benefit of the security interests in the Collateral described below under “—Security” and will mature on          , 2030. Each note will bear interest at a rate of      % per annum from the Issue Date or from the most recent date to which interest has been paid or 157 ----- provided for, payable semiannually to holders of record at the close of business on         or immediately preceding the interest payment date on         and         of each year, commencing       , 2023.

On or after       , 2026, the Issuer may redeem the notes at its option, in whole at any time or in part from time to time, upon not less than 10 nor more than 60 days’ prior notice mailed by the Issuer by first-class mail to each holder’s registered address, or delivered electronically if held by DTC, at the following redemption prices (expressed as a percentage of principal amount), plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date (subject to the right of holders of record on the relevant record date to receive interest due on the relevant interest payment date), if redeemed during the 12-month period commencing on         of the years set forth below:

2026 ..................................................................................................................................... % 2027 ..................................................................................................................................... % 2028 and thereafter .............................................................................................................. 100.000% In addition, prior to       , 2026, the Issuer may redeem the notes at its option, in whole at any time or in part from time to time, upon not less than 10 nor more than 60 days’ prior notice mailed by the Issuer by firstclass mail to each holder’s registered address, or delivered electronically if held by DTC, at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the notes redeemed plus the Applicable Premium as of, and accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the applicable redemption date (subject to the right of holders of record on the relevant record date to receive interest due on the relevant interest payment date). Notwithstanding the foregoing, at any time and from time to time prior to       , 2026, the Issuer may redeem in the aggregate up to 40% of the original aggregate principal amount of the notes (calculated after giving effect to any issuance of additional notes) in an amount not to exceed the amount of net cash proceeds of one or more Equity Offerings (1) by the Issuer or (2) by any direct or indirect parent of the Issuer to the extent the net cash proceeds thereof are contributed to the common equity capital of the Issuer or used to purchase Capital Stock (other than Disqualified Stock) of the Issuer, at a redemption price (expressed as a percentage of the principal amount thereof) of      %, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date (subject to the right of holders of record on the relevant record date to receive interest due on the relevant interest payment date); _provided, however, that at least 50% of the original aggregate principal amount of the notes (calculated after giving_ effect to any issuance of additional notes) must remain outstanding after each such redemption (unless, in either case, all notes are redeemed or repurchased, or are to be redeemed or repurchased, substantially concurrently); _provided, further, that such redemption shall occur within 180 days after the date on which any such Equity Offering_ is consummated upon not less than 10 nor more than 60 days’ notice mailed by the Issuer to each holder of notes being redeemed, or delivered electronically if held by DTC, and otherwise in accordance with the procedures set forth in the indenture. The indenture shall also provide that, in connection with any tender offer or exchange offer (including a Change of Control Offer or an Asset Sale Offer), if holders of not less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the outstanding notes validly tender and do not withdraw such notes in such offer and the Issuer, or any third party making such offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases all of the notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuer or such third party will have the right, upon not less than 10 nor more than 60 days’ prior written notice to the holders (with a copy to the Trustee), given not more than 30 days following such purchase, to redeem all notes that remain outstanding following such purchase at a price in cash equal to the price offered to the holders in such offer (excluding any early tender or incentive fee) plus, to the extent not included in the tender offer or exchange offer payment, accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the date of redemption. Notice of any redemption upon any corporate transaction or other event (including any Equity Offering, Incurrence of Indebtedness, Change of Control or other transaction) may be given prior to the completion thereof. In addition, any redemption described above or notice thereof may, at the Issuer’s discretion, be subject to one or more 158 ----- conditions precedent, including, but not limited to, completion of a corporate transaction or other event. If any redemption is so subject to the satisfaction of one or more conditions precedent, the notice thereof shall describe each such condition and, if applicable, shall state that, in the Issuer’s discretion, the redemption date may be delayed until such time as any or all such conditions shall be satisfied (or waived by the Issuer in its sole discretion), and/or such redemption may not occur and such notice may be rescinded in the event that any or all such conditions shall not have been satisfied (or waived by the Issuer in its sole discretion) by the redemption date, or by the redemption date as so delayed, and/or that such notice may be rescinded at any time by the Issuer if the Issuer determines in its sole discretion that any or all of such conditions will not be satisfied (or waived). For the avoidance of doubt, if any redemption date shall be delayed as contemplated by this paragraph and the terms of the applicable notice of redemption, such redemption date as so delayed may occur, subject to the applicable procedures of DTC, at any time after the original redemption date set forth in the applicable notice of redemption and after the satisfaction (or waiver) of any applicable conditions precedent, including, without limitation, on a date that is less than 10 days after the original redemption date or more than 60 days after the applicable notice of redemption. In addition, the Issuer may provide in such notice that payment of the redemption price and performance of the Issuer’s obligations with respect to such redemption may be performed by another Person.

In the case of any partial redemption, selection of notes for redemption will be made by the Trustee in compliance with the requirements of the principal national securities exchange, if any, on which the notes are listed (and the Issuer shall notify the Trustee of any such listing), or if the notes are not so listed, on a pro rata basis to the extent practicable or by lot or by such other method as the Trustee shall deem fair and appropriate (and, in such manner that complies with the requirements of DTC, if applicable); provided that no notes of a minimum of $2,000 or less shall be redeemed in part. Except with respect to a Special Mandatory Redemption, notices of redemption will be mailed by first-class mail (or with respect to global notes, to the extent permitted or required by applicable DTC procedures or regulations, sent electronically) at least 10 but not more than 60 days before the redemption date to each holder of notes to be redeemed at its registered address, except that redemption notices may be mailed or sent more than 60 days prior to a redemption date if the notice is issued in connection with a defeasance of the notes or a satisfaction and discharge of the indenture or if the redemption date is delayed as described above. If any note is to be redeemed in part only, the notice of redemption relating to such note shall state the portion of the principal amount thereof to be redeemed. A new note in principal amount equal to the unredeemed portion thereof will be issued in the name of the holder thereof upon cancellation of the original note. On and after the redemption date, interest will cease to accrue on notes or portions thereof called for redemption so long as the Issuer has deposited with the paying agent funds sufficient to pay the principal of, plus accrued and unpaid interest (if any) on, the notes to be redeemed.

Subsection Title: Mandatory Redemption; Offers to Purchase; Open Market Purchases
Subsubsection Text: Except under the circumstances described under the caption “—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption,” the Issuer will not be required to make any mandatory redemption or sinking fund payments with respect to the notes. However, under certain circumstances, the Issuer may be required to offer to purchase notes as described under the captions “—Change of Control” and “—Certain Covenants—Asset Sales.” We may at any time, and from time to time, purchase notes in the open market or otherwise.

Subsection Title: Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption
Subsubsection Text: If this offering closes prior to the Merger Closing Date, concurrently with the closing of this offering of the notes the Issuer will enter into an escrow agreement (the “Escrow Agreement”) among the Issuer, the Trustee and J.P. Morgan Chase Bank, N.A., as escrow agent (in such capacity, the “Escrow Agent”), pursuant to which the Issuer will deposit or cause to be deposited the gross proceeds of this offering of the notes (the “Proceeds”) into the Escrow Account, together with an additional amount of cash and/or Cash Equivalents in an amount that, when taken together with the Proceeds and with the rights to receive any cash and/or Cash Equivalents under one or more letters of credit or one or more Sponsor Escrow Interest Commitment Letters, would be sufficient (as determined in good faith by the Issuer) to redeem the notes at a price equal to 100% of the issue price thereof plus an amount equal to the interest that would accrue on such notes to, but excluding, July 31, 2023. No later than the date that is three Business Days prior to the last day of each month beginning with July 31, 2023 and ending with December 31, 2023 159 ----- (in each case, unless the Escrow Release Date or a Special Mandatory Redemption has occurred and subject to the immediately succeeding sentence), the Issuer will deposit (or cause to be deposited) to the Escrow Account an additional amount of cash and/or Cash Equivalents equal to the interest that would accrue on the notes to, but excluding, the last day of the next succeeding month (in each case, as calculated in accordance with the terms of the indenture). At the option of the Issuer, funds managed by Affiliates, or certain investment Affiliates, of the Sponsors and the Co-Investors will (i) enter into one or more equity commitment letters pursuant to which they will, among other things, agree to contribute cash and/or Cash Equivalents directly or indirectly to the Issuer in an amount equal to all or a portion of the accrued and unpaid interest on the notes to the Special Mandatory Redemption Date in the event that the Special Mandatory Redemption occurs (each, a “Sponsor Escrow Interest Commitment Letter” and collectively, the “Sponsor Escrow Interest Commitment Letters”) and/or (ii) in lieu of all or a portion of such amount, deposit or cause to be deposited an amount of cash and/or Cash Equivalents (either in the form of cash or letters of credit). The Sponsor Escrow Interest Commitment Letters, if applicable, will automatically terminate on the earliest to occur of (i) the completion of the Special Mandatory Redemption and (ii) the date of satisfaction of the Escrow Conditions (as defined below). The initial funds deposited in the Escrow Account, and all other funds, securities, interest, dividends, distributions and other property and payments credited to the Escrow Account (less any property and/or funds paid in accordance with the Escrow Agreement), are referred to, collectively, as the “Escrowed Property.” As long as Escrowed Property is deposited with the Escrow Agent, subject to the terms of the Escrow Agreement, the Escrow Agent will invest the Escrowed Property in such Cash Equivalents as the Issuer will from time to time direct in writing. The Issuer will grant, for the benefit of the Trustee and the holders of the notes, a firstpriority security interest in the Escrow Account and the Escrowed Property to secure the Notes Obligations pending disbursement as described below. The ability of the holders of the notes to realize upon such funds or securities held in the Escrow Account may be subject to certain bankruptcy law limitations in the event of a bankruptcy of the Issuer or the Escrow Agent. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Escrow of Proceeds—If a bankruptcy or reorganization case is commenced, the escrowed funds might be deemed to be property of the bankruptcy estate such that bankruptcy laws may prevent the release of funds in the escrow account and the holders of the notes might become unsecured creditors.” The Issuer may cause the Escrow Agent to release the Escrowed Property by delivering to the Escrow Agent and the Trustee, on or before the Escrow Outside Date, an Officer’s Certificate (the “Escrow Officer’s _Certificate”) instructing the Escrow Agent to release the escrowed funds and certifying to the effect that:_ (1) the Merger will be consummated on the date of release of the Escrowed Property in all material respects as described under “Summary—The Transactions”; (2) the Issuer has entered into the Credit Agreement and the ABL Facility or will substantially concurrently with the release of the Escrowed Property enter into the Credit Agreement and the ABL Facility; and (3) equity investments in the Issuer, directly or indirectly, by funds affiliated with the Sponsors and the Co-Investors will have been made and borrowings under the Credit Agreement and the ABL Facility will be available in an aggregate amount sufficient, when taken together with the Escrowed Property and the cash and Cash Equivalents of the Company, to consummate the Merger and to pay related fees and expenses (clauses (1), (2) and (3), collectively, the “Escrow Conditions”). In the event that upon the earliest of (x) the date on which the Issuer determines in its sole discretion that the Escrow Conditions cannot be satisfied, (y) the end of the day on the Escrow Outside Date, if the Escrow Officer’s Certificate has not been delivered by such time and (z) the date on which the Issuer notifies the Escrow Agent and the Trustee in writing that (i) the Issuer will not pursue the consummation of the Merger and/or (ii) the Merger Agreement has been validly terminated (such earliest date, the “Special Termination Date”), the Issuer will be required to redeem all of the notes (the “Special Mandatory Redemption”) on the Special Mandatory Redemption Date at the Special Mandatory Redemption Price. The Issuer will deliver or cause to be delivered notice of a Special Mandatory Redemption to the Trustee and the Escrow Agent, and mailed by first-class mail to each holder’s registered address, or delivered electronically 160 ----- if held by DTC, no later than one Business Day following the Special Termination Date. Such notice will provide that all of the notes shall be redeemed in accordance with the terms of the indenture on the Special Mandatory Redemption Date. In connection with such Special Mandatory Redemption, the Escrow Agent will release funds from the Escrow Account to the Trustee, and the Trustee shall pay such amounts to the paying agent (if other than the Trustee), in connection with the Special Mandatory Redemption. Upon the deposit of funds sufficient to pay the Special Mandatory Redemption Price in respect of the notes to be redeemed on the Special Mandatory Redemption Date with the Trustee or the paying agent on or before such date, the notes will cease to bear interest and all rights under the indenture and the notes shall terminate. If at any time the Escrow Account contains cash and Cash Equivalents having an aggregate value, together with the amount of commitments under the Sponsor Escrow Interest Commitment Letters and the face amount of any letters of credit, in excess of the Special Mandatory Redemption Price, upon written instruction of the Issuer to the Escrow Agent, such excess cash and Cash Equivalents may be released to (or at the direction of) the Issuer or the amount of commitments under such Sponsor Escrow Interest Commitment Letters or the face amount of any such letters of credit may be reduced. On the Special Mandatory Redemption Date, upon written instruction of the Issuer, the Trustee will pay to (or at the direction of) the Issuer any Escrowed Property in excess of the amount necessary to effect the Special Mandatory Redemption, plus any outstanding fees and expenses of the Trustee and Escrow Agent. If the Issuer is able to consummate the Merger on the Issue Date, then the Issuer may elect to forego the escrow procedures described above in their entirety, in which case there would be no Escrow Agreement, Escrow Account or Sponsor Escrow Interest Commitment Letters. No provisions of the Escrow Agreement (including, without limitation, those relating to the release of the Escrowed Property) may be amended or waived in a manner that would materially adversely affect the holders of the notes (as determined in good faith by the Issuer) without the consent of the holders of a majority in principal amount of the notes then outstanding. No provisions of the indenture with respect to the Issuer’s obligation to redeem the notes through a Special Mandatory Redemption may be amended or waived in a manner that would materially adversely affect the holders of the notes without the consent of each holder of an outstanding note affected. “Escrow Account” means a segregated account that includes only cash and Cash Equivalents, the proceeds thereof and interest earned thereon. “Special Mandatory Redemption Date” means the fifth Business Day after the Special Termination Date. “Special Mandatory Redemption Price” means a price equal to the issue price of the notes plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the Special Mandatory Redemption Date.

Subsection Title: Activities Prior the Release of Escrow Proceeds
Subsubsection Text: Prior to the Escrow Release Date, the primary activities of the Issuer will be restricted to issuing the notes, issuing Capital Stock to, and receiving capital contributions from, Holdings or any other parent entity, performing its obligations in respect of the notes under the Indenture and the Escrow Agreement, performing its obligations under the Merger Agreement, redeeming the notes, if applicable, and conducting such other activities as are necessary or appropriate in connection with the Transactions or to carry out the activities described above.

The indebtedness evidenced by the notes and the Subsidiary Guarantees, respectively, will be senior Indebtedness of the Issuer and the Subsidiary Guarantors, respectively, will rank pari _passu in right of payment with all existing and future senior Indebtedness of the Issuer and the Subsidiary Guarantors and will be senior in right of payment to all existing and future Subordinated Indebtedness of the Issuer and the Subsidiary Guarantors. In the event that the Merger is not consummated on the Issue Date, the notes will have the benefit of a first-priority security interest in the Escrow Account and the Escrowed Property so long as the proceeds of any notes remain in the Escrow Account. From and after the Escrow Release Date, pursuant to the Security Documents, the First Lien 161 ----- Intercreditor Agreement and the ABL Intercreditor Agreement, the notes and the Subsidiary Guarantees will have the benefit of (i) a first-priority security interest in the Notes Priority Collateral, which will also secure all other First-Priority Obligations on a first-priority basis and the ABL Obligations on a junior-priority basis and (ii) a second-priority security interest in the ABL Priority Collateral, which will also secure the ABL Obligations on a first-priority basis and the First-Priority Obligations on a second-priority basis, in each case, subject to Permitted Liens and exceptions described under the caption “—Security.” From and after the Escrow Release Date, the Notes Obligations will rank effectively senior to the ABL Obligations, to the extent of the value of the Notes Priority Collateral, and effectively junior to the ABL Obligations, to the extent of the value of the ABL Priority Collateral. From and after the Escrow Release Date, the Notes Obligations will be pari passu with all other First-Priority Obligations, to the extent of the value of the Notes Priority Collateral and the ABL Priority Collateral, will rank effectively senior to all unsecured Indebtedness of the Issuer and the Subsidiary Guarantors and to all Indebtedness of the Issuer and the Subsidiary Guarantors secured by junior liens on the Collateral, in each case, to the extent of the value of the Collateral, and will be effectively subordinated to all future Indebtedness of the Issuer and the Subsidiary Guarantors that is secured by assets or properties not constituting Collateral securing the notes. At March 31, 2023, on a pro forma basis after giving effect to the Transactions, the Issuer and its Subsidiaries would have had (a) approximately $4,100.0 million in aggregate principal amount of outstanding Indebtedness constituting First-Priority Obligations, consisting of the notes and $2,300.0 million (equivalent) outstanding under the Credit Agreement and (b) approximately $677.9 million of borrowings available and undrawn under the $1,400.0 million ABL Facility (as a result of estimated borrowing base availability of approximately $1,307.2 million and after giving effect to approximately $500.0 million expected to be drawn as of the Merger Closing Date and approximately $129.3 million of letters of credit expected to be outstanding as of the Merger Closing Date). Certain hedging, cash management and bank product arrangements that are entered into with the lenders under the ABL Facility will be secured by the same collateral that secures the ABL Facility. Although the indenture will limit the Incurrence of Indebtedness and the issuance of Disqualified Stock by the Issuer and its Restricted Subsidiaries, and the issuance of Preferred Stock by the Restricted Subsidiaries of the Issuer that are not Subsidiary Guarantors, such limitation is subject to a number of significant qualifications and exceptions. The Issuer and its Subsidiaries are able to Incur additional amounts of Indebtedness. Under certain circumstances the amount of such Indebtedness could be substantial and, subject to certain limitations, such Indebtedness may be Secured Indebtedness, including Secured Indebtedness constituting ABL Obligations or additional First-Priority Obligations. See “—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Incurrence of Indebtedness and Issuance of Disqualified Stock and Preferred Stock” and “—Certain Covenants—Liens.” Unless a Subsidiary is a Subsidiary Guarantor, claims of creditors of such Subsidiary, including trade creditors, and claims of preferred stockholders (if any) of such Subsidiary, generally will have priority with respect to the assets and earnings of such Subsidiary over the claims of creditors of the Issuer, including holders of the notes. The notes, therefore, will be effectively subordinated to holders of indebtedness and other creditors (including trade creditors) and preferred stockholders (if any) of any Subsidiary of the Issuer that is not a Subsidiary Guarantor. As of the Escrow Release Date, the Issuer’s only Subsidiaries that will not be Subsidiary Guarantors will be (i) Foreign Subsidiaries, (ii) non-Wholly Owned Subsidiaries and (iii) Domestic Subsidiaries that (w) are Immaterial Subsidiaries, (x) are prohibited by any applicable contractual requirement or requirement of law from guaranteeing the notes on the Escrow Release Date or that would require consent, approval, license or authorization of a Governmental Authority to guarantee the notes (unless such consent, approval, license or authorization has been received), including special purpose Subsidiaries, (y) are FSHCOs or (z) are Subsidiaries of (A) any of the Subsidiaries described in preceding clauses (ii) or (iii) or (B) any Foreign Subsidiary that is a CFC. As of March 31, 2023, on a historical basis, the Issuer’s non-guarantor Subsidiaries had approximately 36% of the Issuer’s total assets and approximately $387.0 million of outstanding indebtedness, excluding intercompany obligations. During the twelve months ended March 31, 2023, on a historical basis, the non-guarantor Subsidiaries would have generated approximately 34% of the Issuer’s total operating revenues and approximately 34% of the Issuer’s Reported Adjusted EBITDA (as defined in this offering memorandum). The foregoing information with respect to the non-guarantor Subsidiaries does not give effect to pro forma adjustments for the Transactions. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Indebtedness and the Notes—The notes will be structurally subordinated to all liabilities of our non-guarantor subsidiaries.” 162 -----

The Capital Stock and securities of a Subsidiary that are owned by the Issuer or any Subsidiary Guarantor will constitute Collateral only to the extent that such Capital Stock and securities can secure the notes or the Subsidiary Guarantee, as applicable, without Rule 3-10, Rule 3-16, Rule 13.01 or Rule 13.02 of Regulation S-X under the Securities Act (or any other law, rule or regulation) requiring separate financial statements of such Subsidiary to be filed with the SEC (or any other governmental agency). In the event that Rule 3-10, Rule 3-16, 165 ----- Rule 13.01 or Rule 13.02 of Regulation S-X under the Securities Act requires or is amended, modified or interpreted by the SEC to require (or is replaced with another rule or regulation, or any other law, rule or regulation is adopted, which would require) the filing with the SEC (or any other governmental agency) of separate financial statements of any Subsidiary due to the fact that such Subsidiary’s Capital Stock or securities secure the notes or any Subsidiary Guarantee, then the Capital Stock and/or securities of such Subsidiary shall automatically be deemed not to be part of the Collateral (but only to the extent necessary to not be subject to such requirement). In such event, the Security Documents may be amended or modified, without the consent of the Trustee or any holder of notes, to the extent necessary to release the security interests on the shares of Capital Stock and securities that are so deemed to no longer constitute part of the Collateral. In the event that Rule 3-10, Rule 3-16, Rule 13.01 or Rule 13.02 of Regulation S-X under the Securities Act is amended, modified or interpreted by the SEC to permit (or is replaced with another rule or regulation, or any other law, rule or regulation is adopted, which would permit) such Subsidiary’s Capital Stock or securities to secure the notes in excess of the amount then pledged without the filing with the SEC (or any other governmental agency) of separate financial statements of such Subsidiary, then the Capital Stock and/or securities of such Subsidiary shall automatically be deemed to be a part of the Collateral (but only to the extent that will not result in such Subsidiary being subject to any such financial statement requirement). In such event, the Security Documents may be amended or modified, without the consent of the Trustee or any holder of notes, to the extent necessary to subject to the Liens under the Security Documents such additional Capital Stock and securities, on the terms contemplated herein. Because the notes do not have registration rights, this limitation will not limit the Collateral on the Escrow Release Date.

Subject to certain limitations and exceptions, if the Issuer or any Subsidiary Guarantor creates any additional security interest upon any property or asset (other than Excluded Property) to secure any First-Priority Obligations or ABL Obligations (which include Obligations in respect of the Credit Agreement and ABL Facility), it must concurrently grant a security interest with the priority required by the Notes Documents (subject to Permitted Liens) upon such property as security for the notes. Also, if granting a security interest in such property requires the consent of a third party, the Issuer will use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain such consent with respect to the security interest for the benefit of the First-Priority Collateral Agent on behalf of the Trustee and the holders of the notes. If such third party does not consent to the granting of the security interest after the use of such commercially reasonable efforts, the applicable entity will not be required to provide such security interest.

The Issuer, the Subsidiary Guarantors and the First-Priority Collateral Agent will enter into the Security Documents on the Escrow Release Date defining the terms of the security interests that secure the notes and the Subsidiary Guarantees. These security interests secure the payment and performance when due of all of the Obligations of the Issuer and the Subsidiary Guarantors under the notes, the Subsidiary Guarantees, the indenture and the Security Documents (and other First-Priority Obligations, which include Obligations in respect of the Credit Agreement), as provided in the Security Documents. We will use our commercially reasonable efforts to perfect all security interests in the Collateral on or prior to the Escrow Release Date. With respect to any owned real properties to be mortgaged as security for the notes, if any, mortgages may not be recorded prior to the Escrow Release Date, and with respect to any other Collateral in respect of the notes, security interests may not be granted prior to the Escrow Release Date. In the event such mortgages are not in place or actions to perfect a security interest in other Collateral have not been completed on or prior to the Escrow Release Date, the Issuer agrees to use commercially reasonable efforts to cause first-priority mortgages to be recorded with respect to our owned real properties (other than Excluded Property) if any, and, where applicable, to obtain title insurance policies insuring the first-priority mortgages on the properties, in each case, subject to local law limitation in granting of security to more than one secured party, and to cause the taking of additional actions required to perfect the security interest in the other Collateral required to be pledged hereunder, in each case within 120 days following the Escrow Release Date.
